A concept defined as the opposing but complementary qualities of interrelated entities/ phenomena in the natural world.
Yin is the opposite of yang. The qualities of yin include cold/cool, dimness, descending, stillness, introversion, heaviness, etc.
Yang is the opposite of yin. The qualities of yang include warm/hot, bright, ascending, movement, extroversion, light, clearness, etc.
Yin qi is the opposite of yang qi. The qualities of yin qi include condensation, moistening, inhibition, etc.
Yang qi is the opposite of yin qi. The qualities of yang qi include warming, activating, excitation, etc.
Yin and yang mutually affect and interact with one another.
Yin and yang mutually oppose and restrain one another.
Yin and yang mutually support one another.
null
Yin and yang have reciprocal roots and cannot be separated.

English term: Yin and yang wax and wane
English definition/description: Dynamic waxing and waning between yin and yang.
Under certain circumstances, yin may transform into yang and yang into yin.
When yin develops to its extremity, it will transform into yang.
When yang develops to its extremity, it will transform into yin.
A harmonious state between yin and yang, when yin qi is in balance and yang qi is secured within the body.

English term: Spontaneous harmonization between yin and yang
English definition/description: The tendency for yin and yang to spontaneously and mutually harmonize.
Without yang, yin cannot come into being.
Without yin, yang cannot grow and develop.
When yin is further divided into yin and yang, the yin aspect of yin is called yin within yin.
When yin is further divided into yin and yang, the yang aspect of yin is called yang within yin.
When yang is further divided into yin and yang, the yang aspect of yang is called yang within yang.
When yang is further divided into yin and yang, the yin aspect of yang is called yin within yang.
When yang qi brings things to life, yin qi grows and enables endurance.
In regard to the changing seasons, it is the nature of yang to kill and break things down and the nature of yin to store.
A collective term for Jueyin, Shaoyin and Taiyin; Shaoyang, Yangming and Taiyang.
null
The interactions and changes among the five categories of phenomena represented by wood, fire, earth, metal and water.

English term: Wood is characterized by bending and straightening
English definition/description: The nature of wood is to bend and straighten as it grows. The wood element is used to express growth, bearing upwards, effusion, free flow, etc.

English term: Fire is characterized by flaming upward
English definition/description: The nature of fire is to flame upwards. The fire element is used to express warmth, rising, flourishing, etc.

English term: Earth is characterized by sowing and reaping
English definition/description: The soil of the earth is where crops are sown and reaped. The earth element is used to express transformation, carrying, embracing, etc.

English term: Metal is characterized by yielding and changing
English definition/description: The nature of metal is to be adaptable and changeable. The metal element is used to express chilliness, descending, purification, etc.

English term: Water is characterized by moistening and descending
English definition/description: The nature of water is to be moist and flow downwards. The water element is used to express coldness, moistening, downward movement, storing, etc.

Synonyms: Mutual generation among the five elements
English definition/description: The five elements mutually engender and support one another. The sequential engendering and supporting relationships among the five elements are, specifically, wood generates fire, fire generates earth, earth generates metal, metal generates water and water generates wood.

Synonyms: Mutual controlling among the five elements
English definition/description: The five elements mutually control and restrain one another. The sequential restraining relationships among the five elements are, specifically, wood restrains earth, earth restrains water, water restrains fire, fire restrains metal, and metal restrains wood.

English term: The five elements mutually control and transform
English definition/description: A balanced, harmonized state maintained by mutual generating and restraining relationships among the five elements.

English term: The five elements overcome and retaliate
English definition/description: The five elements have the actions of overcoming and retaliating with one another.

English term: The five elements mutually over-restrain one another
English definition/description: Excessive restraint of an element over the element it controls.

English term: The five elements mutually counter- restrain one another
Synonyms: Reverse restraining/ insulting among the five elements
English definition/description: A restraining element becomes controlled by the element it controls.
In the five elements, the qi of one element gives birth to the succeeding element.
In the five elements, the qi of one element is born from the previous element.
In the five elements, when an illness in the mother organ is passed to the child organ.
In the five elements, when an illness in a child organ affects the mother organ.
The five directions are east, west, south, north and center. In the five elements, they are associated with wood, metal, fire, water and earth respectively.
A fifth seasonal period occurring between the seasons of summer and autumn. It can also refer to the period of the last eighteen days of each season.
The five seasons are spring, summer, late summer, autumn and winter. In the five elements, they are associated with wood, fire, earth, metal and water respectively.
The prevailing climate qualities of the five seasons are wind, summer heat, dampness, dryness and cold. In the five elements, they are associated with wood, fire, earth, metal and water respectively.
The five transformative states are birth, growth, transformation, harvest and storage. In the five elements, they are associated with wood, fire, earth, metal and water respectively.
The five colours are green, red, yellow, white  and black. In the five elements, they are associated with wood, fire, earth, metal and water respectively.

The five flavours are sour, bitter, sweet, pungent and salty. In the five elements, they are
associated with wood, fire, earth, metal and water respectively.
The five musical notes are juÃ© (mi), zhÇ(sol), gÅng (do), shÄng (re), and yÇ” (la). In the five elements, they are associated with wood, fire, earth, metal and water respectively.

The wordâ€œzangâ€means the internal organs; and the wordâ€œxiangâ€means the outward manifestations of physiological functions and pathological changes of the internal organs.
A collective term for the internal organs of human beings, including five zang organs, six fu organs and extraordinary organs.
A collective term for the five internal organsâ€”the heart, liver, spleen/pancreas, lung and kidney.
A collective term for the six internal organs: gallbladder, stomach, large intestine, small intestine, urinary bladder, and sanjiao (literally translated intoâ€œtriple energizerâ€).
A collective term for brain, marrow, bone, vessels, gallbladder and uterus. These organs are extraordinary because they store like zang organs.

The zangâ€“fu organs mutually correspond with one another, with a (yin) interiorâ€“(yang) exterior connection between the zang and fu organs.
Specifically, the heart is internallyâ€“externally connected with the small intestine, the lung with the large intestine, the spleen with the stomach, the liver with the gallbladder, the kidney with the urinary bladder, and the pericardium with sanjiao.

English definition/description: The heart stores the spirit; the lung stores the corporeal soul; the liver stores the ethereal soul; the spleen stores the intent; and the kidney stores the will.

English term: Governance of the five zang organs
English definition/description: The heart governs blood vessels; the lung governs the skin; the spleen governs the flesh; the liver governs the sinew/tendon; and the kidney governs the bones.

English definition/description: The fluid of the heart is sweat; the fluid of the lung is nasal mucus; the fluid of the spleen is thin saliva; the fluid of the liver is tears; and the fluid of the kidney is the thick saliva.

Stomach qi descends the initially digested chyme to the small intestine and eliminates the waste from the body.

English term: The large intestine governs the thin body fluids
English definition/description: The large intestine absorbs the thin, clear fluids while eliminating waste.

A fu organ. A collective term for upper jiao, middle jiao and lower jiao. It serves as a pathway for qi and water circulation and dominates qi transformation.
The upper jiao is located above the diaphragm and includes the heart and lung.
The middle jiao is located between the diaphragm and navel and includes the spleen, stomach, liver and gallbladder.
The lower jiao is located below the navel and includes the kidney, urinary bladder, large intestine, and small intestine.
The heart and lung distribute qi and blood. Their function is compared with the permeation of mist and dew.
The spleen and stomach decompose water and food. Their function is compared to fermentation.
The kidney and urinary bladder regulate water discharge. Their function is compared to an unobstructed ditch.

English term: The house of the original spirit
English definition/description: Refers to the brain â€“ the source of mental activities.
Refers to the head â€“ a place where the spirit, qi, essence and marrow converge.
An extraordinary organ. A collective term for brain marrow, spinal cord and bone marrow. Marrow is transformed from kidney essence.
An extraordinary organ that stores bone marrow, supports the body, protects the internal organs, and helps with body movements.
An extraordinary organ, referring to the pathway for qi and blood circulation.

English term: Hair is the extension of blood
English definition/description: The growth of hair depends on the nourishment of blood.
An extraordinary organ. A collective term for female internal genital organs.

Synonyms: The office of the servant and messenger
English definition/description: It refers to the pericardium that acts to protect the heart against exogenous pathogenic factors.

The intangible, high-mobility nutritive substance that maintains vital activities.

A collective term for essence and qi. It serves as the fundamental substance of the human body and maintains vital activities.
A general term referring to various changes generated by qi movement. All things in the universe are transformed by qi.
Qi movement can be classified into four basic forms, namely ascending, descending, exiting and entering.
A collective term for qi of the entire body, including innate qi and acquired qi.

Synonyms: Pre-heaven qi; prenatal qi; congenital qi
English definition/description: The qi inherited from oneâ€™s parents and stored in the kidney.
The qi transformed from the essential qi of water and food as well as the clean qi (fresh air inhaled in the lung) of the nature.
Rooted in the kidney, Yuan-primordial qi consists of innate essence qi and Ying-nutrients qi transformed from water and food. It includes primordial yin qi and primordial yang qi.
The qi that accumulates in the chest. It consists of clean qi (fresh air inhaled in the lung) in the nature and qi transformed from water and food.
Opposite to Wei-defensive qi. Ying-nutrients qi is transformed from water and food and travels within the blood vessels.
The qi within blood and yin within qi. When used in combination with blood, it often represents yin blood. Alternatively, it generally refers to blood.
Ying-nutrient is yin and flexible in nature and travels within the vessels.
Opposite to the Ying-nutrient qi. It travels outside the vessels and is transformed from the nutrients of water and food.

Pinyin term: wÃ¨i xÃ­ng mÃ i wÃ i
English definition/description: Wei-defence is yang and resolute in nature. It travels outside the vessels.
The qi stored in the zangâ€“fu organs and maintains normal physiological functions of the zangâ€“fu organs.
It is also known as qi of the spleen and stomach.
The qi circulates within the meridians and falls under the category of healthy qi.
The basic forms of qi movement.
Qi has the function of warming the body.
Blood has the function of nourishing and moistening the body.
The thin, clear and high-mobility body fluids that distribute over the skin, muscles or orifices and permeates into blood vessels. This part of fluids moistens the body.
The thick, low-mobility body fluids that perfuse into the bones, joints, zangâ€“fu organs, brain and marrows. This part of fluids nourishes the body and lubricates the bones/joints.

English term: Qi is the commander of the blood
Pinyin term: qÃ¬ wÃ©i xuÃ¨ zhÄ« shuÃ i
English definition/description: This refers to the functions of qi in transforming, circulating and governing blood.
Qi can transform into blood. Blood is transformed from nutrients from water and food and Ying- nutrient qi within the blood vessels.
The heart qi, lung qi and liver qi maintain the normal circulation of blood.

Synonyms: Qi holds blood; Qi contains blood
English definition/description: This refers to the normal functioning of spleen qi and liver qi in keeping the blood circulating within the blood vessels.

English term: Blood is the mother of qi
English definition/description: Blood transforms into and carries qi.
The function of tangible blood in carrying intangible qi.
Qi of the zangâ€“fu organs transforms into and engenders body fluids.
Qi of the zangâ€“fu organs promotes the normal distribution of body fluids.

Synonyms: Qi holds body fluids; qi contains body fluids
English definition/description: Qi keeps the body fluid within the waterways and maintains its normal circulation.
The function of tangible body fluids in carrying intangible qi.

English term: Body fluids and blood share the same source
English definition/description: Body fluids and blood are both transformed from nutrients found in water and food; the two mutually generate each other.

English term: Essence and blood share the same source
English definition/description: Essence qi and blood are both transformed from nutrients of water and food; the two mutually generate each other.

English term: Blood and sweat share the same source
English definition/description: Since blood is composed of body fluids and Ying- nutrient qi and sweat is transformed from body fluids, the blood and sweat share the same source.
The normal fire that benefits growth.
The normal fire generates the Yuan-primordial qi and maintains vital activities.
null
All causes of diseases.

English term: To differentiate pattern to reveal an etiology
English definition/description: A method to seek the etiological factors according to clinical manifestations.
A theory that classifies etiological factors into internal, external and neither internal nor external.
These mainly refer to seven emotional disturbances.
These mainly refer to six exogenous pathogenic factors.

English term: Neither internal nor external etiological factors
English definition/description: Pathogenic factors that are not categorized as external or internal, such as improper diet, over- exertion, traumatic injuries, animal/insect bites, drowning etc.
Pathogenic factors that attack the body through the skin, mouth and nose, including six pathogenic factors and epidemic qi.
Internal dysfunctions due to extreme emotions, over-exertion, and improper diet.
Opposite to healthy qi, it is a collective term for all pathogenic factors.
Opposite to yin pathogens, refers to pathogenic factors of yang nature, such as wind, summer-heat or fire-heat.
Opposite to yang pathogens, refers to pathogenic factors of yin nature, such as cold or dampness.

Opposite to excess pathogens, it is a collective term for exogenous pathogenic factors that invade the body when the body is weak. Alternatively,
it refers to pathogenic qi that transmits from the mother organ to the son organ.
Opposite to deficiency pathogens, it is a collective term for pathogenic factors. Alternatively, it refers to pathogenic qi that transmits from the son organ to the mother organ.
A collective term for epidemic, etiological factors associated with the four seasons.
External pathogenic factors that damage the human body.
A collective term for six exogenous pathogenic factors: wind, cold, summer-heat, dampness, dryness and fire.
A collective term for exogenous pathogenic factors with high contagiousness.
A pathogenic factor with high contagiousness.
Seven normal emotions include joy, anger, anxiety, overthinking, grief, fear and fright.
A collective term for damage caused by extreme emotions including joy, anger, anxiety, overthinking, grief, fear and fright.
Fire pattern transformed from disturbance of joy, anger, grief, overthinking and fear.
Diet harmful to health, including unhealthy dietary habits, ingestion of contaminated food, dietary preference, etc.
A collective term for over-exertion and physical inactivity.
A pathogenic factor that induces or aggravates medical conditions by errors of health care professionals.
Harm to the body by animals or insects.
A pathogenic factor characterized by opening the skin pores, high mobility and upward/outward movement.
Wind loosens the interspace between skin/muscle fibers and opens the skin pores, resulting in sweating and aversion to wind.
Wind is characterized by upward flowing. It easily affects the head, face, surface of the body and yang meridians.
Wind is characterized by constant moving. It causes the limbs to tremble.

Pinyin term: fÄ“ng shÃ n xÃ­ng shuÃ² biÃ n
English definition/description: Wind is characterised by swift changes. Diseases caused by wind are marked by a sudden onset of symptoms in moving locations.

English term: Wind is the leading cause of diseases
Pinyin term: fÄ“ng wÃ©i bÇi bÃ¬ng zhÄ« zhÇng
Synonyms: Wind is the spearhead of a hundred diseases
English definition/description: Wind may cause a wide variety of conditions. It is the spearhead of exogenous pathogenic factors and liable to associate itself with cold, dampness, dryness and heat.
A pathogenic factor characterized by coldness, stagnation, congealing and contraction.
Cold is yin in nature and can easily impair yang qi.
Pathogenic cold causes qi/blood to stagnate, blocks meridians, and causes pain.
Pathogenic cold constricts qi, blocks the skin pores, and causes contractions.
A pathogenic factor commonly seen between the summer solstice and beginning of autumn. It is characterized by flames ascending and dispersing.
Pathogenic summer heat is characterized by extreme hotness. Often causes hyperactive yang heat.
Summer heat ascends and disperses. Often directly affects the qi phase, opens the sweating pores and damages body fluids.

English term: Summer heat often combines with dampness
English definition/description: Summer is hot, humid and rainy. The summer heat provokes dampness and is often liable to mix itself with dampness.
A pathogenic factor that obstructs the flow of qi. It is characterized by heaviness, turbidity, stickiness and downward flowing.
Dampness is a tangible pathogenic factor and is easy to obstruct qi movement.
Dampness is yin in nature and can easily damage yang qi. It is tangible and can obstruct the flow of yang qi.
Pathogenic dampness is characterized by its heaviness and turbidity. The diseases caused by it may lead to heaviness of the body and turbidity of secretions and excrements.
Dampness is characterized by stickiness and stagnation. It causes sticky, viscous secretions and discharges. Dampness-induced conditions often last a long time.
Dampness move downward and affects the yin and lower parts of the body.
A pathogenic factor that consumes body fluids and tends to damage the lung.
Dryness desiccates by consuming body fluids and causing body fluid deficiency and lack of moisture.
Dryness invades the body through the nose, mouth and skin pores. It easily damages the lung fluids and impairs the dispersing of lung qi.
A pathogenic factor that flames upward, consumes qi and body fluids, engenders wind, stirs blood, and harasses the heart spirit.
A pathogenic factor that causes excessive pathological changes of hot and yang nature.
A collective term for pathogenic warm heat, including spring warmth, wind warmth, summer heat warmth, damp warmth, autumn dryness, winter warmth, pestilence warmth, warm toxin, warm malaria, etc.
Toxic pathogens include toxins transformed from six exogenous pathogenic factors, toxic fire from sores/ulcers, toxic heat, snake venom, rabies or toxic lacquer.
The nature of pathogenic fire flames upward. It causes heat symptoms and often affects the upper part of the body.
Fire tends to stir liver wind. Extreme heat can cause stirring of wind.
Since fire may burn the vessels and collaterals and cause the blood to move recklessly, it often results in bleeding or macular eruption.

English term: Fire consumes qi and body fluids
Pinyin term: huÇ’ hÃ o qÃ¬ shÄng jÄ«n
English definition/description: Since fire consumes healthy qi and scorches yin fluids, it often causes deficiency of both qi and thin fluids.

English term: Fire tends to disturb the heart spirit
Synonyms: Fire tends to disturb the heart Shen
English definition/description: Since fire tends to disturb the heart spirit, it often causes mental restlessness.
Since fire heat tends to enter the blood and remain in a fixed location, it often causes sores/ ulcers.
Hyperactive, pathogenic fire that consumes healthy qi.
Excessive anger damages liver qi, impairs the function of liver in maintaining the free flow of qi, causes the qi to rise, and results in disordered qi and blood.
Excessive joy damages heart spirit, consumes heart qi and results in mental derangement.
Excessive overthinking damages spleen qi, causes qi to stagnate, and impairs the function of the spleen in transportation and transformation.
Excessive grief damages and consumes lung qi and impairs the dispersal of lung qi.
Excessive fear damages kidney qi, causes kidney qi to descend, and impairs the function of the kidney in storing essence.
Improper diet, including excessive hunger and binge eating.
Intake of contaminated or poisonous food.
Excessive indulgence in specific food, including cold or hot food, certain flavours or alcohol.
The five flavours are spicy, sweet, sour, bitter and salty. Habitual preference for a particular flavour or taste may bring about adverse reactions or damage the five zang organs.
Overwork can be physical, mental or sexual.
Excessive physical activities damage the zangâ€“fu organs and cause qi deficiency of the zang organs.
Excessive mental activities tend to damage heart blood and spleen qi.
Excessive sexual activities consume and damage kidney essence.
Physical inactivity leads to imbalances in the flow of qi and blood, weak tendons and bones, stagnant qi of the spleen and stomach. In severe cases, it may even cause other secondary diseases.

The five exhaustions are listed as follows: Long- time observation damages blood; long-time lying damages qi; long-time sitting damages muscles; long-time standing damages bones; and long-time walking damages sinews. Alternatively, the five overstrains refer to deficiencies of the five zang organs (i.e. liver, heart, spleen, lung and kidney).
A collective term for stagnation of qi, blood, phlegm, fire, food and dampness. Often results from qi stagnation of the liver and spleen.

Refers to the seven pathogenic factors that lead to deficiency and consumption, including improper diet, anxiety, drink, sex, hunger, over-exertion, and damage to meridians, collaterals, Ying-nutrients, Wei-defense and qi.

Associated with fluid retention. It refers to the viscous, turbid pathological products that
accumulate in the body due to disordered water metabolism. It can be an etiological factor for a variety of diseases.
Tangible phlegm is visible, touchable and audible when it is secreted from the airways.
Intangible phlegm is invisible and impalpable; however, it can cause pathogenic features of phlegm.

The spleen governs transportation and transformation of water and food. The failure of the spleen to transport and transform water fluids may cause internal retention of water dampness and generate phlegm.
The lung dominates water and regulates the water passage. The failure of the lung to disperse qi may cause internal retention of phlegm fluids.

Fluid retention is relative to phlegm. It refers to the thin, clear pathological products that accumulate in the body due to disordered water metabolism. It can also be an etiological factor for a variety of diseases.
Fluid retention that lasts a long period of time. It is one type of fluid retention.
A type of fluid retention that is deeply located and hard to remove.
A pathological product formed during slow blood flow or as blood coagulates. It is also a secondary pathogenic factor.
The gravel-like substance that accumulates in the human body, especially in the ducts and cavities of zangâ€“fu organs. It is also a secondary pathogenic factor.
An inherited etiological factor that transmits the body constitution and disease of the mother to her fetus.
A pre-birth toxin. It is a pathogenic factor that causes infantile skin rashes.
A collective term for a congenitally weak constitution and a deficiency of qi and blood. It is a major contributing factor to a deficiency of healthy qi.
Congenital constitutional weakness is an internal etiological factor of healthy qi deficiency.
The five pathological states of wind, fire, cold, dryness and dampness due to dysfunctions of the zangâ€“fu organs.

Opposite to external wind, it is a pathological state of yang qi hyperactivity and wind stirring due to disordered qi and blood of the zangâ€“fu organs.
This includes extreme heat generating wind, liver yang transforming into wind, blood deficiency generating wind and yin deficiency stirring wind.
Opposite to external cold, it is a pathological state of deficiency cold due to yang qi deficiency of the zangâ€“fu organs.
Opposite to external dampness, it is a pathological state of retained water, dampness, phlegm and turbidity due to dysfunctions of the zangâ€“fu organs and disordered water metabolism.
Opposite to external dryness, it is a pathological state of body fluids failing to moisten the body.
Opposite to external fire, it is a pathological state of fire heat due to disordered qi, blood, yin and yang of the zangâ€“fu organs.
The pathogenic fire produced from improper diet, fatigue, joy, anger, grief, overthinking, qi deficiency or yang deficiency.
null
The mechanism of the occurrence, progress, and change of the disease.

Opposite to pathogenic factors, it is a collective term for physiological functions of the body, including the bodyâ€™s ability to adapt to the external environment, defend against pathogens and recover from diseases.
Opposite to the latent pathogenic qi in the theory of warm disease, it often causes a sudden onset of disease.
Opposite to exposure to acute pathogenic qi in the theory of febrile diseases, it causes the occurrence of diseases after a period of time.
A rapid appearance of symptoms after being in contact with a pathogen.
A gradual appearance of symptoms after being in contact with a pathogen.
Relapse of diseases due to etiological or inducing factors.
Relapse of diseases due to intake of improper diet or intake of contaminated food.
Relapse of disease due to the damage to healthy qi by overwork
A pathological state of pathogenic factors affecting two meridians that are interiorâ€“exteriorly connected.
Transmission and transformation of diseases among five zang organs.
Two or more external pathogenic factors invade the body. Alternatively, it means exogenous pathogenic factors triggering previously existing diseases.

Pinyin term: xiÃ© hÃ i kÅng qiÃ o
English definition/description: Pathological states caused by pathogenic factors invading the mouth, nose, ears and eyes.

English term: Struggle between anti- pathogenic qi and pathogenic factors
English definition/description: The struggle between healthy qi and pathogenic factors determines the pathogenic nature of diseases. Alternatively, it is specifically used to explain the pathogenesis of alternating fever and chills in Shaoyang disease due to cold damage.

English term: Waxing and waning of anti-pathogenic qi and pathogenic factors
English definition/description: The pathological states due to the struggle between healthy qi and pathogenic factors.
Opposite to deficiency, it is a hyperactive pathological state due to a fierce struggle between excessive pathogenic factors and normal healthy qi.
Opposite to excess, it is a hypoactive pathological state due to the struggle between weak healthy qi and mild/moderate pathogenic factors.
A pathological state due to deficiency of healthy qi and excess of pathogenic factors. This includes deficiency complicated with excess and excess complicated with deficiency.
A pathological state that mainly manifests as a deficiency of healthy qi, accompanied by excessive pathogenic factors.
A pathological state that mainly manifests as excess of pathogenic factors, accompanied by a deficiency of healthy qi.

English term: True or false deficiency and excess
English definition/description: The false symptoms contrary to the true nature of the disease. This includes true deficiency with false excess and true excess with false deficiency.
The false excess symptoms due to extreme deficiency of healthy qi.
The false deficiency symptoms due to extreme excess of pathogenic factors.
The mutual transformation between deficiency of healthy qi and excess of pathogenic factors. This includes excess transforming into deficiency and deficiency into excess.
A transformation from an excess pattern (hyperactivity of pathogenic factors) to a deficiency pattern (deficiency of healthy qi).
A transformation from a deficiency pattern (deficiency of healthy qi) to an excess pattern (hyperactivity of pathogenic factors).

A general term for pathological states due to waxing and waning of yin and yang. This includes excess of yin or yang, deficiency of yin or yang, mutual impairment between yin and yang, rejection between yin and yang, transformation between yin and yang, and depletion/loss of yin or yang.
Pathological states due to excess of yin or yang.
Coexisting yin waxing and yang waning. Over time, excess yin cold may damage yang qi and result in yang depletion.
Mutual restraint between yin and yang maintains relative yinâ€“yang equilibrium. The failure of yang to restrain yin may cause relative yin excess.
Coexisting yang waxing and yin waning. Often develops when waxing yang severely damages yin; however, yin damage is more severe.

English term: When yang prevails, yin fluids will be consumed.
English definition/description: A pathological state of overwhelming yang heat consuming yin fluids.
A pathological state of overwhelming yang leading to excess heat.

English term: When yin prevails, yang qi will be impaired.
English definition/description: A pathological state of excess yin cold consuming yang qi.
A pathological state of overwhelming yin leading to excess cold.
Pathological states due to deficiency of yin or yang.
A pathological state of yang qi deficiency leading to deficiency cold.
A pathological state in which yin fluid fails to control yang and causes a relative hyperactivity of yang and deficiency heat.

English term: Yin deficiency leading to yang hyperactivity
English definition/description: A pathological state in which yin fluid fails to control yang and causes a relative hyperactivity of yang.

English term: Yin deficiency leading to fire hyperactivity
English definition/description: A pathological state in which yin fluid fails to control yang and causes a relative hyperactivity of yang and deficiency fire.

English term: Mutual impairment between yin and yang
English definition/description: A pathological state of deficiency of both yin and yang. Often results from severe deficiency of yin affecting yang or vice versa. This includes yin deficiency affecting yang and yang deficiency affecting yin.

A pathological state in which yang qi deficiency impedes the generation of yin, resulting
in deficiency of both yin and yang with a preponderance of yang deficiency.
A pathological state in which consumption of yin affects yang qi, resulting in deficiency of both yin and yang with a preponderance of yin deficiency.

English term: Dual deficiency of yin and yang
English definition/description: A pathological state of coexisting yin deficiency and yang deficiency.

A serious pathological state in which extremely excessive yin in the interior forces the deficient yang to spread outward or extremely excessive yang in the interior keeps deficient yin on the outside, forming pseudo-heat or pseudo-cold. This includes excessive yin rejecting yang and excessive yang rejecting yin.
A pathological state of true cold with false heat when interior yin cold due to extreme yang deficiency forces the deficient yang to float on the exterior of the body.
A pathological state of true heat with false cold when interior yang heat blocks the movement of qi and forces the yin to float on the exterior of the body.
A pathological state of upward floating of yang qi due to excessive yin rejecting yang or loss/ consumption of essence blood.
A critical state of sudden, heavy loss of yin fluid or yang qi. This includes yin collapse and yang collapse.
A critical state of massive loss and sudden failure of yin fluid.
A critical state of massive loss and sudden failure of yang qi.
A pathological state of exhaustion of yin fluid and loss of yang qi.
A critical state of separation between yin and yang due to extreme deficiency of yin and yang.
Disordered activity of qi in ascending, descending, entering and exiting. It may cause qi stagnation, adverse qi flow, qi sinking, qi blockage and qi exhaustion.

A general term for dysfunctions of the zangâ€“fu organs. It is often used to explain dysfunctions of qi of the zangâ€“fu organs in ascending the clear and descending the turbid. It may cause hiccups, chest stuffiness, abdominal distension/pain and irregular bowel/bladder movements.
A pathological state of decreased zangâ€“fu functions or body weakness due to deficiency of qi.
A pathological state in which extreme deficiency of qi causes qi to float on the exterior of the body.
A pathological state in which qi is obstructed inside.
A pathological state of reversed upflow of qi. Either excessive upward flow of qi or inhibited downward flow of qi.
A pathological state in which qi fails to lift or hold but flows downward.
A pathological state in which the movement of qi is inhibited.
Stagnant movement of qi. It is often associated with emotions and disorder of qi and blood. Often refers to liver qi stagnation.
A pathological state of prolonged qi stagnation transforming into fire heat.
A pathological state in which deficient blood fails to nourish the zangâ€“fu organs and meridians/ channels.
A pathological state of slow, coagulated or stagnant circulation of blood.
A pathological state in which cold enters the blood phase and causes the blood to stagnate or coagulate.
A pathological state in which heat enters the blood phase and causes the blood to move recklessly.

English term: Blood failing to flow within the vessels
English definition/description: A pathological state in which blood moves recklessly out of the vessels.

English term: Blood failing to nourish the sinews
English definition/description: A pathological state in which liver blood fails to nourish the sinews and causes muscle/tendon spasm.
Any failure in the mutually coordinating relationship between qi and blood.

English term: Dual deficiency of qi and blood
English definition/description:
A pathological state of malnourishment of the body or weakened bodily function due to
simultaneous presence of qi deficiency and blood deficiency.
A pathological state in which the dysfunction of qi affects the blood and causes blood deficiency, stagnant blood or bleeding.

English term: Reckless flow of blood due to heat
English definition/description: A pathological state of bleeding due to heat in the blood stirring or consuming blood and forcing it out of the vessels.

English term: Qi collapse following loss of thick fluids
English definition/description: A critical state in which a massive loss of bodily fluids causes sudden collapse/loss of yang qi.

English term: Qi failing to transform thin fluids
English definition/description: A pathological state in which yang qi fails to vaporize water and perform qi transformation.

English term: Water retention obstructing the flow of qi
English definition/description: A pathological state in which retained water within the body impedes the qi ascending, descending and transformation of the zangâ€“fu organs.

English term: Blood stasis due to qi stagnation
English definition/description: A pathological state in which stagnant qi affects the circulation of blood and causes simultaneous presence of qi stagnation and blood stasis.

English term: Blood stasis due to qi deficiency
English definition/description: A pathological state in which qi fails to promote the circulation of blood and causes blood stasis, resulting in simultaneous presence of qi deficiency and blood stasis.
A pathological state in which qi fails to contain blood and allows the blood to flow out of the vessels.

English term: Qi collapse following heavy blood loss
English definition/description: A critical state in which massive blood loss causes sudden collapse of qi.
A pathological state in which upward adverse flow of qi leads to blood rushing upward and results in haematemesis, haemoptysis or stroke.
A pathological state in which the thin, clear fluids are consumed.

A pathological state of emaciation and functional failures of the zangâ€“fu organs. Alternatively,
it can be a life-threatening sign due to major consumption of heavy, thick fluids.

English term: Fluid exhaustion leading to blood dryness
English definition/description: A pathological state in which fluids fail to supplement blood and causes blood dryness and internal dry heat.

English term: Dual deficiency of qi and yin
English definition/description: A pathological state of simultaneous presence of qi deficiency and yin deficiency.

English term: The water gate failing to operate
English definition/description: A pathological state in which dysfunctions of the kidney in qi transformation causes inhibited urination (dysuria) and oedema.

A pathological state of yinâ€“yang disharmony and hyperactive yang transforming into fire. Alternatively, it occurs when prolonged intake of pungent, warm-property aphrodisiacs generates internal fire toxins and consumes essence qi.

English term: Disharmony between the Ying-nutrients and Wei-defence
English definition/description: A pathological state of lack of coordination between the Ying-nutritive qi and Wei-defensive qi.
A pathological state of spontaneous sweating without fever due to deficiency of the Wei- defensive qi (in an exterior pattern).
A pathological state of sweating that occurs only during fever in an exterior pattern.

Pinyin term: xiÃ ng huÇ’ wÃ ng dÃ²ng
Synonyms: Frenetic stirring of the ministerial fire
English definition/description: A pathological state of upward flame of fire due to yin deficiency of the liver and kidney. Common symptoms may include dizziness, headache, blurred vision, tinnitus, deafness, irritability, dream-disturbed sleep, feverish sensations in the palms, soles and chest, hypersexuality, nocturnal emissions, premature ejaculations, etc.
null
The activities to maintain physical and mental health and prevent illnesses.
The congenital life expectancy

English term: Preventing a disease before it arises
English definition/description: A concept to prevent a disease before it arises and prevents transmission of a disease after its onset.

English term: Preventing a disease before it arises
English definition/description: A method to strengthen the healthy qi and eliminate potential harmful factors to prevent the occurrence of a disease.

English term: Preventing transmission of a disease after its onset
English definition/description: A method to use early diagnosis and early intervention to prevent disease progression and transmission.

English term: Protecting yang in spring and summer
English definition/description: Yang qi rises and grows in the spring and the summer. It is necessary to protect and nourish the internal yang qi to keep it sufficient along with the seasons.

English term: Nourishing yin in autumn and winter
English definition/description: Everything is stored in the autumn and the winter. It is necessary to protect and store the internal yin essence to keep it internally accumulated along with the seasons.
The physical appearance and the mental activities are inseparable. The robust physical appearance and sound vitality is the sign of bodyâ€“mind wellness.

English term: Regulating spirit according to four seasonal qi
English definition/description: The adjustment of mental activities along with the climate of four seasons.
null

A collective name of wood movement, fire movement, earth movement, metal movement, water movement, and the collective name of wind, summer heat (heat), dampness, dryness, fire, cold in the natural world.

The collective name of wood movement, fire movement, earth movement, metal movement, and water movement. It reflects the changes of qi of five elements between heaven and earth. Ten heavenly stems of jia, yi, bing, ding, wu, ji, geng, xin, ren, and gui are used to record the movements.

The six normal climatic phenomena of wind, summer heat (heat), dampness, dryness, fire,  and cold in the natural world. The twelve earthly branches of zi, chou, yin, mou, chen, si, wu, wei, shen, you, xu, and hai are used to record the six qi.
The collective name of jia, yi, bing, ding, wu, ji, geng, xin, ren, and gui.
The collective name of zi, chou, yin, mou, chen, si, wu, wei, shen, you, xu, and hai.

The heavenly stems pair with the earthly branches, following their orders, from jiaâ€“zi to guiâ€“hai, forming a complete cycle of sixty years. The heavenly stems initiate with jia and the earthly branches initiate with zi. The combination is used to number years, months, days and times.

The movement governs the year, being jia and ji in category of earth movement, yi and geng in category of metal movement, bing and xin in category of water movement, ding and ren in category of wood movement, and wu and gui in
category of fire movement. For example, jia and ji is in category of earth movement, the movement of the year of the jia-zi year is earth.

Each of the five movements dominates in spring, summer, later summer, autumn and winter.
Starting from the severe cold and following the order of generating cycle of five elements, the first movement is wood, the second is fire, the third is earth, the fourth is metal, and the fifth is water.

The special climatic changes of the five seasons. It varies in every season in every year. Starting from the movement of the year as the initial movement, calculate in five steps according to the excess and insufficiency order of five elements. Ten years is   a complete cycle and covers ten heavenly stems. Ten years is a complete cycle that covers ten heavenly stems. Then the cycle starts all over agin.

The combination of wind, cold, dampness, dryness, sovereign fire, ministerial fire with host qi in six steps. The initial qi is in association  with Jueyin, wind and wood, the second qi with Shaoyin and sovereign fire, the third qi with Shaoyang and ministerial fire, and the forth qi with Taiyin, dampness and earth, the fifth qi with yang ming, dryness and metal, the sixth (final) qi with Taiyang, cold and water.

The collective name of wind, cold, dampness, dryness, sovereign fire and ministerial fire, being opposed to the guest qi. It reflects the normal seasonal climatic changes of the year. The calculation is to relate twenty four solar terms to six qi in six steps. The four solar terms consist of one step, being six steps for one year. The calculation starts from the severe cold.

1) Reflects the abnormal climatic changes of the year, being opposed to the host qi. It includes the celestial qi, the terrestrial qi, and the four right and left intervening qi. The first yin is in association with Jueyin, wind, and wood, the second yin with Shaoyin and sovereign fire, and the third yin with Taiyin, dampness, and earth. The first yang is in association with Shaoyang and ministerial fire, the second yang with yang ming, dryness, and metal, the third yang with Taiyang, cold, and water. The calculation is to combine the above yinâ€“yang order with twelve earthly branches. 2) External pathogenic factors.
The guest qi governing the climatic changes of the first half of the year.
The guest qi governing the climatic changes of the second half of the year. It is opposite to celestial qi.
The qi left and right to the celestial qi and the qi left and right to the terrestrial qi.
The intervening qi left to the celestial qi becomes the celestial qi and the intervening qi left to the terrestrial qi becomes the terrestrial qi.
The celestial qi becomes the intervening qi right to the celestial qi and the terrestrial qi becomes the intervening qi right to the terrestrial qi.
The excess of qi is restrained and the insufficiency of qi is compensated in the five movements.
The five movements and six qi share the same category of the five elements.
The movement qi of the year and the celestial qi share the same category of the five elements in one year.
The movement qi of the year and the earthly branch of the year share the same category of the five elements in one year.
The heavenly stem and the earthly branch of the year are both yang and the movement of the year and the terrestrial qi share the same category of the five elements in one year.
The heavenly stem and the earthly branch of the year are both yin and the movement of the year and the terrestrial qi share the same category of the five elements in one year.
The movement of the year, the celestial qi, and earthly branch of the year share the same category of the five elements in one year.

English term: Tip qi, root qi and middle qi
English definition/description: The study of relationship between six qi of heaven and six qi of the human body. It is used to determine the principle of the treatment based on interactions between human and nature.
Six qi of heaven, being wind, heat, dampness, dryness, cold and fire.
Qi of six meridians of Shaoyang, Taiyang, Yangming, Shaoyin, Taiyin and Jueyin.
The relationship between the prevailing qi and the retaliating qi in five movements and six qi. They coexist by increasing and decreasing in the same direction.
The qi that is stronger and restrain another qi in the five movements and six qi.
The qi that is weaker and is restrained from another qi in the five movements and six qi.
The fire in the heart. It is opposite to the ministerial fire.
The fire dwelling in the liver, gallbladder, kidney and triple energizer, being opposite to the sovereign fire.
null

The sum total of the knowledge, skills and practices based on the theories, beliefs and experiences indigenous to different cultures, whether explicable or not, used in the maintenance of health as well as in the
prevention, diagnosis, improvement or treatment of physical and mental illness.
A comprehensive system originated in ancient China that involves the study of life, health and diseases.

Pinyin term: zhÅng yÄ« jÄ« chÇ” lÇ lÃ¹n
Synonyms: Basic theory of traditional Chinese medicine
English definition/description: Rational understandings of fundamental knowledge in traditional Chinese medicine. These include essential concepts, regular patterns, theories and principles. These understandings guide the application of traditional Chinese medicine in health preservation and disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment as well as rehabilitation.
The integral entity of the human body. The integration of human beings with nature and society.
Man and nature correspond to each other.
The oneness of human beings, heaven, earth and nature.
1) Dominance of life activities. 2) Outer manifestation reflecting the life activities. 3) State of mind, mood and mental activities.
Mind or spirit. Alternatively, it also refers to all natural phenomena and patterns, including the sun, moon and stars.
Another name of the sweat pore for inflow and outflow of qi.
Another name of the sweat pore for dispersion and flowing of qi and fluid.

Refers to the striae of the skin, muscle and organs, also to the space between the skin, muscle
and organs, the minute passages for the fluid percolation and the flowing of qi and blood.
A collective name of blood wheel, wind wheel, flesh wheel, qi wheel and water wheel for the eye, which is closely related to the physiological conditions or/and pathological changes.
Refers to blood vessels at the canthus of eyes, pertaining to the heart. The heart governs blood. Its disorders are related to the heart.
Refers to the black part of the eye, pertaining to the liver. The liver is the organ of wind and wood. Its disorders are related to the liver.
Refers to the eyelids, pertaining to the spleen. The spleen governs flesh. Its disorders are related to the spleen.
Refers to the white part of the eye, pertaining to the lung. The lung governs qi. Its disorders are related to the lung.
Refers to the pupil, pertaining to the kidney. The kidney governs water. Its disorders are related to the kidney.
Seven major places in the digestive tract, being flying gate, door gate, breathing gate, rushing gate, pylorus, screen gate and corporeal gate.
Another name for lips.
Another name for teeth.
Another name for epiglottis.
Upper opening of the stomach.
Lower opening of the stomach.
Junction between large and small intestines.
Another name for anus.
The external genitals.
Anus.
The area around the lips reflecting the strength and the weakness of the essential qi in the spleen.
The place where the male stores the essence, including testicles, epididymis, seminal vesicles and prostate. It is associated with reproduction.
1) Four limbs. 2) Distal ends of toes and fingers.
1) The gathering venue of pectoral qi, at the centre of the two nipples. 2) Another name of pericardium. 3) Name of an acupuncture point located in the midpoint between two nipples.
The major collateral of the stomach, one of the sixteen collaterals, located at the apex of heart below the left nipple, which is the gathering venue of pectoral qi.
The empty space or depression at the connection of muscles. The large one known as theâ€œvalleyâ€ and the small one as theâ€œcreekâ€.
A term used to refer to: 1) uterus; 2) Chong meridian; or 3) liver.

English term: Gathering of muscle around genital region
English definition/description: 1) Muscle regions of three yang and three yin meridians gathering at the genital regions. 2) Male external genitalia.
The space inferior to the heart and superior to the diaphragm. When used as a disease location, it often means that the condition is incurable.

There are five sense organs, namely, the tongue, nose, mouth, eyes and ears. The throat is also considered as a sense organ. There are a total of nine orifices (seven yang orifices and two yin
orifices), namely, the eyes (2), ears (2), nostrils (2), mouth, anterior yin (external genitalia including the external orifice of the urethra) and posterior yin (anus).
The eyes are categorized into eight regions according to zangâ€“fu theory to match with the eight trigrams. This helps to further categorize and differentiate patterns of eye disease.
The white opaque part of the outer surface of the eyeball, i.e. the conjunctiva and sclera.

The transparent membranous structure forming the central anterior part of the eye, i.e. the cornea. Since this part corresponds to the liver, corneal eye problems are often associated with the liver and gallbladder.

In a narrow sense, it refers to the opening at the centre of the iris, posterior to the cornea, through which light enters the eye. In a broad sense, it refers to the pupil and all attached tissues. Since this part corresponds to the kidney (the water wheel according to the five-wheel theory) and  the liver and kidney share the same source, pupil- related eye problems are often associated with the liver and kidney.
Tears and transparent, watery fluid secreted from the ciliary epithelium.
The clear, colourless gel that fills the space between the lens and the retina of the eyeball.
An ancient term for the nose. It also refers to the chart of the twelve meridians and points in Chinese medicine.
1) An exogenous pathogenic factor. 2) Special odour of the patientsâ€™body, excretion and secretion. 3) Pathological products steamed by damp heat.

English term: 2 Terminologies on diagnosis, patterns and constitution
English definition/description: null
null
Abnormal functions reflecting the presence of an unusual state, or of a disease. It includes a patientâ€™s subjective feelings or manifestations perceived by a doctor.
Abnormal changes that can be objectively measured.
A pathological summarization on the disease location, etiological factors, nature, severity and prognosis in a certain stage.

The whole process of struggle between anti- pathogenic qi and pathogenic factors, yinâ€“yang imbalance and progression, manifesting as specific symptoms and patterns. In a narrow sense, a disease has its specific name.
The process of an overall analysis of clinical data to determine the location, etiological factors and nature of a disease at a certain stage.
The process of differentiating a disease from its whole process and its characteristics according to the etiology, underlying pathology, progression and prognosis.
null

The whole process of applying theories, principles, prescriptions and medicines to clinical treatment. Pattern differentiation aims to analyse the signs and symptoms collected by the four examination methods according to the fundamental theories of the eight principles, zangâ€“fu organs, etiology and pathogenesis. Treatment refers to specific therapeutic methods directed at the differentiated pattern.

English term: Combination of the four diagnostic methods
English definition/description: The process of an overall analysis of clinical data collected through the four diagnostic methods and providing a diagnosis and potential treatment options.
Integrated differentiation of both pattern and disease. This helps to analyse the disease onset and development, and thus provide reliable evidence for practical treatment strategies.

English term: Judging the inside from observing the outside
English definition/description: A method to understand internal pathological changes through observing the external manifestations.
null
null
A method to understand patientsâ€™health condition by observing changes in their body, localized body parts, and excreta.

Bright eyes with flexible eyeballs, clear consciousness, natural facial expressions, a moist lustrous face, a fit body, smooth body movements, and even breathing. The presence of spirit indicates abundant essential qi or a mild medical condition.

Dull eyes with sluggish eyeballs, poor spirit, slow response, a complexion lacking lustre, flabby muscle and slow body movements. The insufficiency of spirit indicates insufficiency of healthy qi or mild impairment to essential qi of zangâ€“fu organs.

Dull eyes with sluggish eyeballs, listlessness or unconsciousness, apathetic expression, slow response, a grey/dark complexion lacking lustre, weight loss and difficult body movements. The loss of spirit indicates severe damage to healthy qi and essential qi failure of zangâ€“fu organs.

Synonyms: The last radiance of the setting sun/the last flicker of life in a dying person
English definition/description:
Suddenâ€˜betterâ€™signs and symptoms in patients with chronic critical conditions: a sudden change from dull eyes with sluggish eyeballs to floating brightness in the eyes; a sudden change from mental unconsciousness or listlessness to clear consciousness and mental restlessness; a sudden change from reluctance to talk and low weak voice into a talkative, clear voice; a sudden change from a grey/dark complexion to flushed cheeks; and a sudden change from no appetite and low food intake into increased appetite and hunger.
The false spirit indicates collapse of healthy qi, extreme essential qi failure of zangâ€“fu organs or imminent separation between yin and yang. This is seen as an omen for a dying person.

The actions of picking or grasping at imaginary objects, as well as the patientâ€™s own clothes or bed linens. Often seen in delirious or semiconscious states, it can be a grave symptom in cases
of extreme qi deficiency or approaching qi exhaustion.
A diagnostic method to observe colour changes of the skin, especially to the face.
With abundant qi and blood as well as functioning of zangâ€“fu organs, a normal facial colour is moist, lustrous and non-exposed red.
The colour one was born with. It remains throughout life. It is determined by race and prenatal factors.
The colour one takes on when physiological, seasonal, climactic, geographic, diet and emotions change the colouring.
Abnormal changes in both colour and lustre of the face under a morbid state.

An abnormal but lustrous complexion, indicating that essential qi of zangâ€“fu organs remain sufficient and stomach qi can ascend to the face. It is often seen in acute, mild conditions or yang pattern that can be easily treated and have a favourable prognosis.

A grey/dark withered complexion, indicating essential qi failure of zangâ€“fu organs and failure of stomach qi to ascend to the face. It is often seen in chronic, critical conditions or yin pattern that can be difficult to deal with and have an unfavourable prognosis.
A method to predict prognosis by observing colour changes (in relation to the host colour) according to the five-element theory. Opposing colour often indicates a poor prognosis.
A bluish or bluish-purple facial complexion often indicates cold, pain, qi stagnation, blood stasis or convulsion.
A red facial complexion often indicates heat or hyperactivity of fire due to yin deficiency.
A yellow complexion can be sallow or yellow coupled with puffiness. Often indicates internal water retention due to spleen deficiency or insufficiency of qi and blood.
A white facial complexion often indicates yang qi failing to circulate blood, consumption of qi and blood or cold contracting the blood vessels.
A black facial complexion often indicates kidney yang failing to transform water or chronic blood stasis.
A pale facial complexion is often mixed with bluish or grey. Often results from severe abdominal pain in an interior cold pattern or insufficiency of qi and blood.
A pale, white facial complexion coupled with puffiness. Often results from water retention due to yang deficiency.
A withered, brown/dark facial complexion. Often results from stomach qi failing to ascend and nourish the face.
A pale, yellow and withered facial complexion lacking lustre. Often results from deficiency of qi and blood due to weakness of the spleen and stomach.
A yellowish facial complexion coupled with puffiness. Often results from internal dampness due to spleen qi deficiency.
A dark facial complexion. Often results from kidney yang failing to transform water, internal yin cold, blood failing to nourish the body or stagnation of qi and blood.
A pale facial complexion with migratory reddening of the cheeks like wearing blush. It is a critical sign indicating yin rejecting yang due to yang qi failure.
Reddening of the cheeks only. Often results from fire hyperactivity due to yin deficiency.

English term: True colours of five zang organs
English definition/description: A withered, lustreless facial complexion. Often results from essential qi exhaustion of the five zang organs.
A noticeable outward curve of the fontanel. Often occurs when pathogenic fire in febrile diseases ascends or when wind heat or damp heat affects the brain.

A sunken fontanel is characterised by a noticeable inward curve. It is often caused by vomiting, diarrhoea, deficiency of qi and blood, deficiency cold of the spleen and stomach, congenital maldevelopment. It is normal for an infant under 6 months of age to have a sunken fontanel.
Uncontrolled, involuntary shaking or tremor of the head. Often results from internal wind or deficiency of qi and blood.
Sudden hair loss in patches, most often on the scalp. Often results from blood deficiency generating wind or emotional stress.
A condition that causes scalp itching, greasy hair, dandruff and hair loss. Often results from blood heat transforming into dryness or internal build up of phlegm dampness.

English term: Deviation of the mouth and eyes
English definition/description: Deviation of the mouth and eyes is characterized by the deviation of the mouth corner towards  the healthy side, facial muscle flaccidity on the affected side and muscle tension on the healthy side, and an inability to completely close the eye and mouth, frown or blow on the affected side. Often results from wind attacking the meridians or wind phlegm obstructing the meridians.
Refers to upward staring with an inability to move the eyes. Often results from internal stirring of liver wind.
Staring blankly with open and fixed eyes. Often results from internal stirring of liver wind or essence exhaustion and loss of spirit.
Twitching of the eyes often results from external wind heat or failure of qi and blood to nourish meridians.
Protrusion of the eyeballs often results from pathogenic fire.

Drooping eyelid is characterized by an inability to open the eyelid and the drooping of the upper eyelid. Often results from congenital deficiency of the spleen and kidney or disharmony between qi and blood after trauma.
Sleep with exposed eyeballs is more commonly seen in children. Often occurs when clean yang fails to ascend due to spleen deficiency or severe damage to bodily fluids.
An aural polyp is a growth in the outside (external) ear canal. Often occurs when damp heat and phlegm fire ascend to cause qi and blood to stagnate in the ear canal.
A nasal polyp is a growth within the nose. Often occurs when toxic damp heat accumulates in the nose.
The lips appear red and swollen. Often results from fire heat scorching the lips.
The lips appear bluish purple, pale purple or dark purple, without lustre or moisture. Often results from blood stasis.
The lips appear pale and have little redness. Often results from deficiency cold or blood deficiency.

The lips appear dry, peeling or chapped. In severe cases, the lips may turn red, swollen or bleeding. Often results from heat accumulating in the spleen and stomach, insufficiency of yin fluids or dry heat consuming bodily fluids.
White ulcerations that occur on the mucous membrane of the oral cavity. Often occurs when damp heat and toxic fire in the spleen and stomach scorches the mouth.
A yellowish or grey/white patch develops on the ulcerative surface of the throat.
A mouth ulcer is often painful. Often results from ascending of accumulated heat in the heart and spleen or fire hyperactivity due to yin deficiency.
The lips become everted. Often indicates approaching exhaustion of spleen qi.
The teeth appear dry and withered. Often results from damage to yin fluids.

A malformation of the chest characterized by a protrusion of the sternum and ribs giving the appearance like the chest of a pigeon. Often results from weak bones due to congenital or acquired deficiency of the spleen and kidney.
Prominent knobs of bone at the costochondral joints that resemble large beads under the skin of the rib cage. Often results from congenital kidney qi deficiency and postnatal malnutrition.

An abnormally excessive convex kyphotic curvature of the spine, resembling the back of a tortoise. Often results from congenital deficiency, postnatal malnutrition and deficiency of the spleen and kidney.
A form of severe malnutrition characterized by emaciation and protrusions of the spine resembling a saw. Often results from severe essential qi deficiency of the zangâ€“fu organs.

Severe hyperextension and spasticity in which an individualâ€™s head, neck and spinal column enter into a completeâ€œbridgingâ€orâ€œarchingâ€position. Often occurs when wind attacks the meridians or wind phlegm obstructs the meridians.

Flaccidity, weakness and muscular atrophy of the four extremities, coupled with loss or impairment of functions. Often results from malnourishment of the muscles or sinews due to damp heat or deficiency of essence and fluids.

Spasticity of the hands and feet with impaired flexion and extension. Often results from cold affecting the meridians or malnourishment of the extremities due to heat scorching yin fluids and resultant blood dryness.

English term: Convulsions of the hands and feet
English definition/description: Slow, weak convulsions of the hands and feet often result from internal stirring of deficiency wind.

English term: Jerking of the hands and feet
English definition/description: Twitching hands and feet in small children. Often results from retention of pathogenic wind in fetal stage, coupled with exposure to wind after birth.
Dry, lustreless fingernails/toenails often result from deficiency of qi and blood, consumption of bodily fluids, external contraction of cold dampness or damage to the liver.
Fusiform swelling of the fingers coupled with impaired movement. Often occurs when wind dampness and phlegm stasis affect the sinews and joints.

Characterized by a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes, also known as drumstick fingers. Often results from lung qi stagnation or qi deficiency of the lung and kidney.

English term: Inspection of superficial veins on index fingers in children
Pinyin term: wÃ ng xiÇo Ã©r shÃ­ zhÇ luÃ² mÃ i
English definition/description: A method to observe the changes in colour and shape of superficial veins on index fingers in children under the age of 3 years. Normal veins are pale red or slightly purple and appear singular with appropriate thickness (neither thick nor thin). Pathologically, the depth of veins indicates an interior pattern from an exterior pattern, colour/ lustres of the veins indicate the disease nature, and shape of the veins indicates deficiency from excess and the three passes (wind pass, qi pass and life pass) indicates the disease severity.
One of the diagnostic sites for infantile venule of the index finger. The wind gate is the area between the metacarpophalangeal transverse crease and the second transverse crease.
One of the diagnostic sites for infantile venule of the index finger. The qi gate is the area between the second and third transverse creases. It indicates a relatively severe condition.

One of the diagnostic sites for infantile venule of the index finger. The life gate is the area between the third transverse crease and terminal segment of the index finger. It indicates a severe medical condition.

English term: Extension of visible veins through all three passes to the nail
English definition/description: This often indicates a life-threatening condition; however, it is necessary to use this method in combination with the four diagnostic methods. This method applies to infants under the age of 3.

Involuntary muscle twitching and mild body shaking often result from water retention (due to yang qi deficiency) affecting the meridians or malnourishment of the meridians due to consumption of fluids.

Rough, scaly skin is often caused by blood deficiency, exhaustion of fluids or
malnourishment of the skin due to chronic blood stasis.

Yin macules appear bluish purple underneath the skin. Individuals may have a pale complexion, a thready, weak pulse and cold limbs. They often result from the spleen failing to control blood within the vessels or cold retention due to yang deficiency.
Yang macules appear red or purple and resemble fabric lines. Individuals may have a red face and fever. They often occur when excessive heat affects the Ying nutrients and blood.
Red, raised, bumpy millet-sized skin rashes. They often result from heat accumulating in the lung and stomach and exuberant heat in the Ying nutrients and blood affecting the skin.
Small, raised white blister-like skin lesions. They often result from retention of externally contracted damp heat in the skin.
Hot, painful millet-sized blisters around the mouth border, lips and nose. They often result from external contraction of wind or ascending of heat accumulated in the lung and stomach.

Local or generalized red, itchy skin rashes that rapidly develop into papules or blisters, followed by oozing upon scratching. Often results from retention of damp heat on the skin coupled with external contraction of wind.
A diagnostic method to inspect the patientâ€™s tongue body and tongue coating.
This refers to changes in the appearance of the tongue, including changes in the spirit, colour and form of the tongue body and its coating.

The two major, dark-red longitudinal vessels on both sides of the frenulum of tongue. Their
lengths do not exceed 3/5 of the distance between the sublingual caruncle and the tip of the tongue. In most cases, they occur singularly, and double vessels are very rare.
The tongue spirit includes its colour, moisture and movement. It is often used to predict disease prognosis.
A lustrous tongue is moistened and fresh red in colour, coupled with flexible movement. Often indicates abundant fluids, qi and blood as well as a high spirit.
A withered tongue is dull, dark, dry and shrivelled, coupled with slow movement. Often indicates deficiency of body fluids, qi and blood as well as a poor spirit.
The tongue body includes the musculature and vascular tissue of the tongue.

The colour of the tongue body. The normal tongue colour is pale red and lustrous. Abnormal colours are pale, red, deep red and purple. A pale tongue indicates blood deficiency or yang deficiency; a red tongue indicates heat in the Wei-defence and qi phases; and a deep red tongue indicates heat in the Ying nutrients and blood phases.
A tongue less red than normal, indicating yang deficiency or deficiency of qi and blood.
A tongue that is totally white, indicating collapse of blood and qi.
A lustrous tongue of normal colour, indicating disharmony between qi and blood. It is often seen in healthy person. In patients, a pale red tongue indicates a mild condition.
A tongue redder than normal, indicating a heat pattern.
A tongue deep red in colour, indicating an intense heat pattern.
A tongue purple in colour, indicating exuberant toxic heat entering the Ying nutrients and blood to consume yin and fluids, and causes stagnation of qi and blood.
A tongue of bluish colour that resembles the exposed blue veins on the skin, indicating blood stagnation due to yin cold obstructing yang qi.
A tongue of pale, bluish colour, often indicating blood stagnation due to yin cold obstructing yang qi or yang qi failing to circulate blood.
A tongue with ecchymosis or petechiae in varying sizes, often indicating stagnation of qi and blood.
A moist tongue is often seen in healthy person. In patients, it indicates that bodily fluids remain undamaged.
The shape of the tongue, including enlargement/ thinness, tough/tender, spotted, cracks or teeth marks.
A tongue that is firm with rough texture and relatively dark in colour, often indicating a struggle between excessive pathogenic factors and strong anti-pathogenic qi.
A tongue that is soft and delicate with fine texture and pale in colour, often indicating deficiency of qi and blood or internal cold dampness due to yang qi deficiency.
A tongue that is larger and thicker than normal, often indicating internal retention of water dampness or ascending of phlegm dampness and toxic heat.
A tongue thinner and smaller than normal, often indicating deficiency of qi and blood or fire hyperactivity due to yin deficiency.
A tongue with red or purple red spots as well as thorn-like protrusions on its surface, often indicating extreme heat in zangâ€“fu organs or exuberant heat in the blood phase.
A tongue with fissures in varying depths and shapes on its surface, often indicating exuberant heat damaging yin, blood deficiency or internal dampness due to spleen deficiency.

Synonyms: Teeth-marked Tongue with dental impressions; Scalloped tongue
English definition/description: A tongue with dental indentations on its margin. It is often seen in an enlarged tongue.

A large, bulging, firm and painful tongue that makes the mouth full or difficult to open and may affect the breathing or speech, often indicating sudden, severe heart fire intertwined with turbid phlegm and stagnant blood.
Spontaneous bleeding from the tongue not due to traumatic injury, often indicating exuberant fire of the heart and liver forces the blood to move recklessly.
The ability of the tongue to move spontaneously. Flexible tongue movement indicates normal functioning of the zangâ€“fu organs with abundant qi and blood.
A tongue that is stiff and moves sluggishly, often indicates heat (in febrile conditions) entering the pericardium, stroke, exuberant heat damaging fluids or wind phlegm obstructing the meridians.
A tongue that involuntarily trembles as it moves; in severe cases, the tongue trembles even when it does not move, often indicating internal stirring of liver wind.

A tongue that hangs out of the mouth repeatedly and tip is extended fast from and retracted slowly back into the mouth, often indicating heat in the heart and spleen, epidemic toxin attacking the heart or exhaustion of anti-pathogenic qi.
A tongue that frequently extends from and retracts back into the mouth and moves in a circular motion, often indicating extreme heat stirring wind.
A tongue that inclines to one side when extended, often indicating wind attacking the meridians or wind phlegm obstructing the meridians.
A tongue that is flabby and cannot move easily, often indicating malnourishment of the sinews or muscles due to deficiency of qi and blood or loss of yin fluids.
A tongue that cannot be fully extended from the mouth and appears to be shortened. It is often seen in combination with a flaccid tongue, often indicating a critical condition.
A tongue that is habitually extended out of the mouth with difficulty retracting or an inability to retract.
A subjective feeling of tongue numbness with inability to move voluntarily. Often occurs when Ying nutrients and blood fail to ascend to nourish the tongue.
A tongue that moves sluggishly, coupled with slurred speech, often resulting from accumulated heat in the spleen and stomach scorching bodily fluids.
A layer of moss-like material covering the tongue, generated by ascending of stomach qi.
A tongue coating through which the underlying tongue surface is faintly visible, indicating normal stomach qi.
A tongue coating through which the underlying tongue surface is not visible, often indicating turbid dampness, phlegm, food retention or heat.
A moist tongue coating with excessive fluid, feels slippery, often indicating internal accumulation of water dampness.
A tongue coating that looks dry and feels dry to the touch, often indicating consumption of bodily fluids.
A tongue coating that is rough in texture that looks and feels dry. A rough coating can be a further development of dry coating, often indicating exuberant heat damaging bodily fluids.
A tongue coating consisting of coarse granules like bean dregs, easy to wipe off, often indicating yang heat steam the undigested food or internal build up of turbid phlegm.
A reddish thick tongue coating with black and yellow tinge, often indicating food retention in the stomach and intestines transforming into heat.
A thick layer of coating that resembles ulcerative pus, often resulting from internal carbuncle or internal retention of toxins.
A dense, turbid, greasy tongue coating with fine texture, sticking on the tongue, hard to wipe off, often indicating internal phlegm dampness obstructing yang qi of the stomach.
A tongue coating that covers the full surface of the tongue, often indicating phlegm dampness.

A tongue with irregular shedding of the coating and distinct demarcation between the shed and unshed areas, looking like a map, often indicating phlegm dampness due to qi deficiency or spleen deficiency coupled with parasitic worms.
A tongue coating that has lost its normal coating, giving the appearance of having been peeled, often indicating deficiency of stomach qi and yin.
A completely smooth tongue free of coating, like a mirror, often indicating stomach yin exhaustion or collapse of yang qi due to heavy loss of Ying nutrients and blood.
Peeling of the tongue coating leaving an unsmooth tongue surface as if covered with regeneration of coating granules, often indicating blood deficiency or deficiency of qi and blood.
A tongue coating that is easy to wipe off.
A tongue coating that is firm and sticky on the tongue body, hard to wipe off.
A tongue coating that is stained, often by food or medicine. A stained coating often resolves spontaneously within a short period of time.
A tongue coating white in colour. A normal tongue coating is often seen in the middle and back part of the tongue with even, moist granules.
A tongue coating that resembles white erosive spots like rice grains, often indicating extreme stomach heat-steaming fluids.
A tongue coating that is white in colour and the tongue body is sticky. Often results from retained dampness in the spleen and stomach.

A tongue coating that is thin, white and moist. It is often seen in a healthy person. In patients, it indicates an early stage of an exterior pattern, a mild interior pattern or internal cold due to yang deficiency.
A tongue coating that is as white as accumulated powder but not dry to touch, often resulting from turbid dampness intertwined with toxic heat.
A tongue coating yellow in colour, often indicating exuberant heat. A darker yellow colour indicates a more intense heat.
A yellow tongue coating that contains grey dark colour, often indicating extreme heat.
A tongue coating grey in colour, often indicating exuberant pathogenic heat, internal yin cold or a build up of phlegm dampness.
A tongue coating black in colour, indicating either excessive yin cold or extreme heat in the interior.
null
A diagnostic method using listening to the changes in: patientsâ€™speech, breathing, cough, internal sounds and smelling the patientsâ€™breath and noticing body odours and discharges.
An expression figuratively referring to sudden hoarseness or loss of voice due to exogenous wind cold or wind heat impairing the dispersing of lung qi.
An expression figuratively referring to hoarseness in chronic or severe medical conditions due to essential qi deficiency of the lung and kidney.
A voice that is faint and low, scarcely audible, often resulting from deficiency of the zangâ€“fu organs.
A low harsh or husky quality of the voice, often resulting from external contraction of wind cold/ heat, qi and yin deficiency of the lung and kidney or impaired lung qi.
Delirious speech, mental cloudiness and a high- pitched sound, often indicating Yangming fu organ pattern or heat disturbing the heart mind due to pathogenic warmth entering the pericardium.
