Meridians and collaterals are pathways for qi and blood to flow throughout the body. They form a comprehensive network linking the tissues and internal organs into an organic whole.

The twelve meridians (i.e. the twelve regular meridians) are: the lung meridian; the large intestine meridian; the stomach meridian; the spleen meridian; the heart meridian; the small intestine meridian; the bladder meridian; the kidney meridian; the pericardium meridian; the Sanjiao meridian; the gallbladder meridian; and the liver meridian.

Pinyin term: shÇ’u tÃ i yÄ«n fÃ¨i jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The lung meridian pertains to the lung and connects with the large intestine. It mainly travels along the anterior border of the medial aspect of the arm.

English term: The large intestine meridian of hand-Yangming
Pinyin term: shÇ’u yÃ¡ng mÃ­ng dÃ  chÃ¡ng jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The large intestine meridian pertains to the large intestine and connects with the lung. It mainly travels along the anterior border of the radial aspect of the arm, passes through the cheeks, enters the lower teeth, and then over the upper lip and terminates beside the opposite nostril.

The stomach meridian pertains to the stomach and connects with the spleen. It starts directly below the pupil between the eyeball and the infraorbital ridge. Running downward along the lateral side of the nose, to the lateral corner of the mouth. Curving posterior to the anterior angle  of the mandible. Then it travels to the posterior aspect of the mandible ascending in front of the ear and following the anterior hairline, it reaches the forehead. It then runs along the throat and enters the supraclavicular fossa. The straight line of the meridian separates the supraclavicular fossa and runs downward along the middle mammillary line. It travels to the side of the umbilicus and descends to the inguinal groove.
Running downward it travels along the anterior aspect of the thigh and reaches the knee. From there is continues further down along the anterior border of the lateral aspect of the tibia to the dorsum of the foot and reaches the lateral side of the tip of the second toe.

Pinyin term: zÃº tÃ i yÄ«n pÃ­ jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The spleen meridian pertains to the spleen and connects with the stomach. It mainly travels along the anterior border of the medial aspect of the leg and passes through the chest and abdomen.

Pinyin term: shÇ’u shÃ o yÄ«n xÄ«n jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The heart meridian pertains to the heart and connects with the small intestine. It mainly travels along the posterior border of the ulnar palmar aspect of the arm.

English term:
The small intestine meridian of
hand-Taiyang
Pinyin term: shÇ’u tÃ i yÃ¡ng xiÇo chÃ¡ng jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The small intestine meridian pertains to the small intestine and connects with the heart. It mainly travels along the posterior border of the dorsal ulnar aspect of the arm, passes through the shoulder and reaches the face.

Pinyin term: zÃº tÃ i yÃ¡ng pÃ¡ng guÄng jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The bladder meridian pertains to the urinary bladder and connects with the kidney. It is mainly distributed over the head, back and along the back of the leg.

Pinyin term: zÃº shÃ o yÄ«n shÃ¨n jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The kidney meridian pertains to the kidney and connects with the urinary bladder. It mainly travels along the posterior border of the medial aspect of the leg and passes through the chest and abdomen, finally terminating at the root of the tongue.

Pinyin term: shÇ’u juÃ© yÄ«n xÄ«n bÄo jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The pericardium meridian pertains to the pericardium and connects with the Sanjiao. It mainly travels along the palmar aspect of the upper arm and moves towards the forearm running between the tendons of the m. palmaris longus and m. flexor carpi radialis.

Pinyin term: shÇ’u shÃ o yÃ¡ng sÄn jiÄo jÄ«ng
Synonyms:
Triple-burner meridian
Triple warmer meridian
Triple energizer meridian of hand-Shaoyang
English definition/description: The Sanjiao meridian pertains to Sanjiao and connects with the pericardium. It is mainly distributed along the dorsal aspect of the forearm between the radius and ulna and reaches the ears and face.

Pinyin term: zÃº shÃ o yÃ¡ng dÇn jÄ«ng
English definition/description: The gallbladder meridian pertains to the gallbladder and connects with the liver. It is mainly distributed over the head, sides of the head, chest, and abdomen and descends down to the lateral aspect of the leg.

The liver meridian pertains to the liver and connects with the gallbladder. It mainly travels along the medial aspect of the leg, passes over the chest and abdomen, and its divergent meridian reaches the vertex.
The three hand-yin meridians are lung meridian, heart meridian and pericardium meridian.
The three hand-yang meridians are large intestine meridian, small intestine meridian and Sanjiao meridian.
The three foot-yin meridians are spleen meridian, kidney meridian and liver meridian.
The three foot-yang meridians are stomach meridian, bladder meridian and gallbladder meridian.

The eight extraordinary meridians are different from the twelve regular meridians with special distributions and functions. They are Du meridian, Ren meridian, Chong meridian, Dai meridian, Yinwei meridian, Yangwei meridian, Yinqiao meridian and Yangqiao meridian.
The Du meridian is mainly distributed over the head, face and along the midline of the back.
The Ren meridian is mainly distributed over the neck, face and along the midline of the chest and abdomen.
The Chong meridian is mainly distributed over the chest and face, inside the spine and along the first lateral line of the abdomen.
The Dai meridian is mainly distributed over the waist, subcostal area and abdomen. It encircles the waist like a girdle.
The Yinqiao meridian is mainly distributed over the heel, the medial aspect of the leg, perineum, abdomen, chest, head, and eyes.
The Yangqiao meridian is mainly distributed over the heel, lateral aspect of the leg, thigh, subcostal area, shoulder, head and eyes.

The Yinwei meridian is mainly distributed over the medial aspect of the leg and thigh and ascends along the third lateral line of the abdomen. It reaches the throat and meets with
the Ren meridian at Tiantu (Ren 22) and Lianquan (Ren 23).

The Yangwei meridian is mainly distributed below the external malleolus, the lateral aspect of the leg, and over the subcostal area, shoulder and sides of the head. It meets with the Du meridian at Fengfu (Du 16) and Yamen (Du 15).
Collaterals are branches of meridians, including minute collaterals, blood collaterals and superficial collaterals.
The fifteen collaterals include the collaterals of the twelve meridians, the collaterals of the Du and Ren meridian as well as the major collateral of the spleen.
The sixteen collaterals include the above- mentioned fifteen collaterals plus the major collateral of the stomach.

English term: The great collateral of the spleen
English definition/description: The major collateral of the spleen begins from Dabao (SP 21), emerges at 3 cun below Yuanye (GB 22) and spreads over the chest and subcostal area.

English term: The great collateral of the stomach
English definition/description: The major collateral of the stomach begins from Xuli (the pulsation at the apex of the heart), passes through the diaphragm, connects with the lung and emerges from the left breast.
Superficial vessels visible to the naked eye.
Collaterals on the surface of the body.
Extremely small collaterals.
The twelve divergent meridians branch out from the twelve regular meridians and are deeper in the body. They function to strengthen the connection between internally-externally coupled meridians.

The twelve muscle regions are corresponding sites where the qi and blood of the twelve meridians  to nourish the muscles and tendons. Their distributions are almost the same as that of the twelve meridians.

The twelve cutaneous regions are corresponding sites where the qi and blood of the twelve meridians to nourish the skin. They are generally known as the outward manifestations of the twelve meridians and collaterals.
The wordâ€œGenâ€literally means root. It shares the similar meaning withâ€œBenâ€. The wordâ€œJieâ€ literally means knot. It shares the similar meaning withâ€œBiaoâ€(see Biao and Ben).

The wordâ€œbiaoâ€literally means the tip of tree branches. Here it refers to the head, face and body trunk where meridian qi diffuses. The wordâ€œbenâ€ literally means the trunk of a tree. Here it refers to the four limbs where meridian qi gathers.
Qi streets are the pathways for meridian qi to flow over the head and body trunk. There is a total of four qi streets, respectively on the head, chest, abdomen and lower leg.
The four seas include the sea of marrow, sea of qi, sea of water and food, and sea of blood (sea of the twelve meridians).
The brain is known asâ€œthe sea of marrowâ€.
The chest is known asâ€œthe sea of qiâ€.

English term: The sea of water and food
English definition/description: The stomach is known asâ€œthe sea of water and foodâ€.
The Chong meridian is known asâ€œthe sea of blood (sea of the twelve meridians)â€.
The Du meridian governs meridian qi of all yang meridians and is therefore known asâ€œthe sea of yang meridiansâ€.
The Ren meridian governs meridian qi of all yin meridians and is therefore known asâ€œthe sea of yin meridiansâ€.

English term: The three branches from one source
Synonyms: The three divergences from a single source
English definition/description: The Du, Ren and Chong meridians all arise from a common origin:â€œbaozhongâ€(the lower abdomen where primordial kidney qi gathers), emerge out of the perineum, and then travels along their own pathways.
Sensations radiating along the pathways of meridians.

Pinyin term: jÄ«ng luÃ² xiÃ n xiÃ ng
English definition/description: Specific disturbance of sensation, transmission of sensation and visible changes in skin colour and quality along the pathways of meridians.
The trachea and throat. The wordâ€œxiâ€means connecting tissues or structures.
The posterior intraocular structures connecting with the brain.
The structures connecting with the heart, such as blood vessels.

English term: The junction between the red and white skin
Synonyms: Junction of the change in skin colour
English definition/description: The boundary between the palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of the hands and feet. The skin on the palm aspect appears white, whereas the skin on the dorsal aspect appears red or brown. It is often used as an anatomical landmark to locate certain points.

Three objects of a door are used figuratively to express the functions of the three yang and
three yin meridians. Of the three yang meridians, Taiyang is compared to the bolt, Yangming to the plank and Shaoyang to the hinge. Of the three yin meridians, Taiyin is compared to the bolt, Jueyin to the plank and Shaoyin to the hinge.

The specific sites where the qi and blood of the zangâ€“fu organs and meridians are transported to the surface of the body. They are pathological reaction points and, at the same time, acupuncture stimulation points.
Acupuncture points of the fourteen meridians (i.e. twelve regular meridians + Du meridian + Ren meridian).
The points that are not contained in the above- mentioned fourteen meridians; however, these points have specific names and locations.
The points of sensitivity or tenderness. They are neither meridians points nor extra points, and they do not have specific names or locations.
The meridians points that have special names and functions.
A collective term of the Jing-well, Ying-spring, Shu-stream, Jing-river and He-sea points. They are all located distal to, or at the elbow and knee joints.
The point at which the qi rises is known as the Jing-well. Most Jing-well points are located on the fingers or toes.
The point at which the qi glides is known as the Ying-spring. The Ying-spring points are generally located distal to the metacarpophalangeal or metatarsophalangeal joints.

The point at which the qi pours through is known as the Shu-stream. The Shu-stream points are generally located proximal
to the metacarpophalangeal joints or metatarsophalangeal joints.
The point at which the qi flows is known as the Jing-river. The Jing-river points are located around the joints of the wrists or ankles.
The point at which the qi enters inwards is known as the He-sea. The He-sea points are located around the joints of the elbows or knees.
The points where the Yuan-primordial qi pools.
The points where a meridian exits off from the main flow and connects with the Yin/Yang paired meridian.
The points where meridian qi is deeply converged.
The points on the back where qi of the respective zangâ€“fu organs is infused.
The points on the chest and abdomen where qi of the respective zangâ€“fu organs is infused.
The points that have particular effects in the treatment of disorders relating to the zang, fu, qi, blood, tendon, vessels, bones and marrow.

Pinyin term: bÄ mÃ i jiÄo huÃ¬ xuÃ©
English definition/description: The points where qi of the twelve regular meridians meets the eight extraordinary meridians.
The points where qi of the six fu organs is infused into the three foot-yang meridians.
The points intersected by two or more meridians.
The selection of different points in acupuncture treatment.
A method to choose points at or close to the affected body area.
A method to choose points away from the affected body area.
A method to choose points according to differentiated pattern.

English term: Point combination of the affected meridian
English definition/description: A method to combine points along the affected meridian.

English term: Point combination of the coupled meridians
English definition/description: A method to combine points from the internally- externally connected meridians.

English term: Point combination of the same-name meridians
Pinyin term: tÃ³ng mÃ­ng jÄ«ng pÃ¨i xuÃ© fÇ
English definition/description: A method to combine points from one hand meridian and one foot meridian that share the same name.

Pinyin term: shÃ ng xiÃ  pÃ¨i xuÃ© fÇ
English definition/description: A method to combine points on the upper and lower body.
A method to combine points on the back and front of the body.
A method to combine points on the left and right side of the body.
A method to combine the Yuan-source and Luo- connecting points.

English term: Hostâ€“guest combination using Yuan-source and Luo- connecting points
Pinyin term: zhÇ” kÃ¨ yuÃ¡n luÃ² pÃ¨i xuÃ© fÇ
English definition/description: A point combination method to use the Yuan- primary point of the affected meridian coupled with the Luo-connecting point of its interiorly- exteriorly connected meridian. This method is often employed to treat problems of the zangâ€“fu organs and meridians.
A method to combine the back-Shu and front-Mu points.
The acupuncture points can be located according to the anatomical landmarks, proportional bone measurement, and finger measurement, etc.

A method to use landmarks on the body surface, primarily joints, to measure the length and width of various parts of the body. Then the width
or length is divided respectively into definite numbers of equal units as the standards for the proportional measurement.
A method to locate acupuncture points based on the finger sizes of the patient.
A method to take the width of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb as 1 cun.
A method to take the distance between the ends of the two radial creases of the interphalangeal joints of the middle finger as 1 cun when the middle finger is flexed.

A method to take the width of the patientsâ€™  four fingers (index, middle, ring and little) close together at the level of the dorsal skin crease of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the middle finger as three cun. It is also known asâ€œYi Fu Faâ€in Chinese.

The sharpest part of a needle.
The part of the needle held by an acupuncturist.
The part between the tip and the handle.
The demarcation line between the handle and the body.
Acupuncture needles made of stainless steel. It is now commonly used in clinical practice.
Acupuncture needles made of silver. They are often used in warming needle because of their good thermal and electrical conduction.
Acupuncture needles made of gold.
Basic acupuncture techniques.
Basic techniques in using filiform needles.
The hand to hold and insert a needle.
The hand that presses the puncturing area with one or more fingers, to facilitate needle insertion.
A method to insert a needle into a point by using both the puncturing hand and pressing hand.
A method to press the skin of puncturing area with the nail of thumb or index finger of the pressing hand and insert the needle against the fingernail with the needling hand.

A method to hold the lower part of the needle body with a piece of sterile cotton or gauze between the thumb and index finger of the pressing hand while inserting a needle. (Press the skin adjacent to the the needling site with the nail of thumb or index finger of the pressing hand, while inserting a needle against the fingernail with the needling hand).
A method to stretch the skin around the puncturing area with the thumb and index finger (or the index and middle fingers) of the pressing hand while inserting a needle.
A method to pinch and lift the skin of the puncturing area with the thumb and index finger of the pressing hand while inserting a needle.
A method to insert a needle into a point by using the puncturing hand alone.
A method to insert a needle using a fine tube as a guide.
A needling technique to prick a point and its surrounding area.

English term: Pricking with a three- edged needle
English definition/description: A needling technique to gently prick using a three- edged needle and let out a small amount of blood or tissue fluid.
A needling technique to prick superficially and then remove immediately. It is often used for Jing- well points or blood-letting.
A needling technique to prick superficial collaterals using a three-edged or a (single- use, disposable) seven-star needle to let out appropriate amount of blood.
The angle formed between the needle body and the skin while the needle is being inserted.
The needle insertion at a 90Â° angle to the skin.
The needle insertion at a 45Â° angle to the skin.
Needle insertion at a 15Â° angle to the skin.
A method to insert a needle from one point towards another point (or more points).
Manipulating the needle after insertion to produce the desired effect.
A needling manipulation to lift and thrust a needle.
A needling manipulation to twirl (turn) or rotate a needle.
A method to gently tap or massage the skin along the pathways of meridians to promote the flow of qi.
A needling manipulation to flick the handle of the needle to promote the flow of qi.
A needling manipulation to scrape the handle of the needle with fingernails to promote the flow of qi.
A needling manipulation to shake the needle handle to promote the flow of qi.

A needling manipulation to twist the needle handle with the thumb and index finger for a couple of times and release the fingers. The repeated twisting and releasing resembles a bird spreading its wings.
A needling manipulation to hold the handle of the needle and make a small-amplitude and rapid lifting and thrusting to cause the needle to vibrate up and down to promote the flow of qi.

The arrival of qi is signalled by particular sensations felt by the patient and the practitioner. For the patient, it typically refers to soreness, numbness, distension and heaviness felt around the needle (but may move up or down along
the meridian). For the practitioner, it refers to a gripping sensation or a feeling of pressure underneath the needle.
Typical sensations of soreness, numbness, distension and heaviness felt around the needle by the patient.
A method to leave the needle in place for a while after insertion, without any manipulation.
A method to manipulate the needle to stimulate the flow of qi.
The effect of needling sensation reaching an affected area.
Needling manipulations to reinforce healthy qi for deficiency pattern and to remove pathogenic factors for excess pattern.

English term: Reinforcing and reducing by twirling or rotating
Synonyms: Tonifying and sedating by twirling or rotating
English definition/description: Needling manipulations to reinforce or reduce according to the twirling/rotating direction, angle, frequency and duration.

English term: Reinforcing and reducing by lifting and thrusting
Synonyms: Tonifying and sedating by lifting and thrusting
English definition/description: Needling manipulations to reinforce or reduce according to the forcefulness, speed, amplitude and duration of the lifting and thrusting.

English term: Reinforcing and reducing by slowness and rapidness
Synonyms: Tonifying and sedating by slowness and rapidness
English definition/description: Needling manipulations to reinforce or reduce according to the slow or rapid needle insertion and withdrawal.
Needling manipulations to reinforce or reduce by going against or following the pathways of meridians.
Needling manipulations to reinforce or reduce by inserting or withdrawing the needle when the patient breathes in or out.

English term: Reinforcing and reducing by opening and closing
Synonyms: Tonifying and sedating by opening and closing
English definition/description: Needling manipulations to reinforce or reduce by opening or closing the needle holes.
Needling manipulations to lift, thrust, or twirl evenly.

A complex reinforcing manipulation to induce local or general warming sensation. The point to be needled is divided into three levels: shallow (heaven), intermediate (man) and deep (earth). Insert the needle into the shallow level first and then down to the intermediate and deep levels, coupled with rapid thrusting and slow lifting for a total of nine times in each level. Repeat the procedure three times and leave the needle in the deep level.

A complex reducing manipulation to induce local or general cool sensation. The point to be needled is divided into three levels: shallow (heaven), intermediate (man) and deep (earth). Insert the needle to the deep level first and then lift to the intermediate and shallow levels, coupled with rapid lifting and slow thrusting for a total of six times in each level. Repeat the procedure three times and leave the needle in the shallow level.

English term: Reinforcing the mother or reducing the son
English definition/description: One of the reinforcing or reducing manipulations. Manipulations of reinforcing the mother or reducing the son are selected according to deficiency or excess of the zangâ€“fu organs or meridian problems.

A special theory for point selection. The midnight- noon (Zi Wu) represents the time. The ebb-flow (Liu Zhu) refers to the circulation of qi and blood. This theory believes the meridian qi and blood flows from Zi time (11:00 pmâ€“1:00 am) to Wu time (11:00 amâ€“1:00 pm) and then from the Wu time to the Zi time. The yin qi becomes most abundant at the Zi time and then begins to decline, and  the Yang qi starts to increase and becomes most abundant at the Wu time. Based on this theory, the five-Shu points located below the knee and elbow joints should be selected according to the designated hours.
To retain a needle in place after the presence of needling sensation (arrival of qi).
To remove a needle when the treatment is done.

Pinyin term: zhÄ“n cÃ¬ yÃ¬ chÃ¡ng qÃ­ng kuÃ ng
English definition/description: Acupuncture-related adverse events include fainting, stuck needle, bent needle and broken needle. These accidents are often caused by  a weak constitution, nervousness, hunger, inappropriate body position or medical negligence.

An adverse event during an acupuncture session: Patients may present with a pale complexion or experience dizziness, nausea and chest tightness. In severe cases, cold limbs, cold sweats, drop in blood pressure, syncope or shock may be present.
Difficulty or impossible to rotate, lift or thrust a needle.
The needle body becomes bent upon insertion or retention.
The needle body is broken and the broken part is on or below the skin surface.
Localized swelling, distension and pain from bleeding in the tissue after needle withdrawal.
Pneumothorax induced by inappropriate acupuncture needling that punctures the lung.
A collective term for acupuncture in a specific local area, such as ear, scalp, or face, etc.
A therapeutic method to stimulate specific lines on the scalp with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the ear with an acupuncture needle.
Specific stimulation areas distributed on the auricles.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the face with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points around the eye socket with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the nose with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the tongue with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the back with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the hand with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the foot with an acupuncture needle.

Pinyin term: wÃ n huÃ¡i zhÄ“n liÃ¡o fÇ
English definition/description: A therapeutic method to stimulate points on the wrist and ankle subcutaneously with an acupuncture needle.
A therapeutic method to stimulate specific abdominal points with an acupuncture needle.

Pinyin term: dÃ¬ Ã¨r zhÇng gÇ” cÃ¨ zhÄ“n fÇ
English definition/description: A method to stimulate the area lateral to the second metacarpal bone with an acupuncture needle. This method is based on micro-system theory that regards the second metacarpal bone as the whole body.
A thick needle with a round handle, a triangular body and a sharp tip similar to a lancet needle. It derives from the Sharp-edged Needle (one of the nine ancient needles).
Needling instrument composed of several short needles used for tapping the points, such as the plum-blossom needle or seven-star needle. These needles cannot be reused without sterilization.
A dermal needle that has a bundle of five short, embedded needles resembling a plum blossom. This needle cannot be reused without sterilization.
A dermal needle that has seven short needles attached to the end of a handle in a cluster. This needle cannot be reused without sterilization.
A small needling instrument for embedding at a certain point for an extended period.
An intradermal needle that is shaped like a thumbtack used for extended auricular therapy, approximately 0.2 mmâ€“1.5 mm in length.
A therapy to insert an intradermal needle into the skin of the body surface (an acupuncture point) and fix with tape to retain for a period of time.
A therapeutic method to connect pulses of electrical current to inserted acupuncture needles.
A therapeutic method to inject fluid, sometimes medicated, into acupuncture points.
A therapeutic method to insert a hot needle to the affected area and remove immediately afterwards.
A therapeutic method to puncture one point towards another one subcutaneously using a long, thready needle like wheat awn. It derives from the Long Needle (one of the nine ancient needles).
A therapeutic method to use a low-energy laser beam to stimulate acupuncture points.
A therapy to use the sting from a live bee (mechanical stimulation) and venom (pharmacological action) in the treatment of health conditions.

A research control method that simulates acupuncture needle insertion without actual insertion, preferably without any penetration that carries physiological response. The tip of a sham needle is blunt to prevent the actual penetration into the body, which effectively trick the patient into thinking they are receiving real acupuncture, such as theâ€œStreitbergerâ€needle.
A therapeutic method to incise the skin to squeeze out a small amount of fat.
A therapeutic method to implant catgut or surgical suture at a selected point.
Pointed or wedge-shaped stones historically used to stimulate the surface of the body, drain pus or let blood out.

A collective term for the nine types of needles described in the Nei Jing (Yellow Emperorâ€™s Internal Classic), namely, shear needle, rounded needle, spoon-like needle, sharp-edged needle, round-sharp needle, sword-like needle, long needle, large needle and filiform needle.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has an arrow- shaped head and often used for superficial insertion in the treatment of heat pattern or skin conditions.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has a cylindrical needle body and oval tip. It is often used for point massage in the treatment of muscle problems.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has a big, thick needle body and a slightly sharp round tip. It is often used for blood problems and heat pattern.

One of the nine ancient needles. It is also known as the three-edged needle. It is often used to prick subcutaneous veins or small vessels in  the treatment of abscess, heat pattern, acute gastroenteritis, etc.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has a round and sharp needle tip and is often used for abscess, bi-impediment and acute conditions.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has a (double- edged) sword-like needle tip and is often used to cut open the abscesses to drain pus and blood.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has a longer needle body (approximately 20â€“30 cm or longer) and is often used for deep insertion in the treatment of chronic rheumatism or sciatica.
One of the nine ancient needles. It has a thick needle body and a slightly round needle tip. It is often used to treat general oedema or abdominal masses.
One of the nine ancient needles. It is now the most common needle in acupuncture treatment.
A collective term for five ancient needling techniques, namely, half needling, leopard-spot needling, joint needling, Hegu needling, and Shu needling.
A technique characterized by a shallow insertion and swift withdrawal. It is often used for lung- related problems.
A technique characterized by pricking with a three-edged needle around the point, causing leopard spot-like haemorrhagic spots. It is often used for heart-related problems.
A technique characterized by puncturing the tendon close to the joint without causing bleeding. It is often used for liver-related problems.

A technique characterized by puncturing the muscles of the affected region with the needle going obliquely right and left, resembling the claws of a chicken. It is often used for spleen- related problems.

English term: Shu needling (one of the five needling techniques)
English definition/description: A technique characterized by deep puncture directly to the bone. It is often used for kidney- related problems.

A collective term for nine ancient needling techniques, namely, Shu needling, distant needling, meridian needling, collateral needling, intramuscular needling, great drainage needling, skin needling, cauterized needling and contralateral needling.

English term: Shu needling (one of the nine needling techniques)
English definition/description: A technique to puncture the Ying-spring point and Shu-stream point of the meridian involved and the back-Shu points of five zang organs.
A technique to puncture points on the lower body (i.e. the lower He-sea points of the six fu organs) to treat problems of the upper body.
A technique to acupuncture stasis/tenderness points along the pathways of meridians.
A technique to prick small vessels with a three- edged needle for bloodletting.
A technique to puncture directly into the muscle.
A technique to incise with a sword-shaped needle to drain pus or eliminate stagnant blood, also known as lancing.
A technique to puncture shallowly into the skin.
A technique to puncture points on the left side if the right side is affected, or vice versa.
A technique to conduct blood-letting on the left side if the right side is affected, or vice versa.
A technique to prick swiftly with a cauterized needle. Indicated for cold bi-impediment pattern.

A collective term for twelve ancient needling techniques, namely: coupled needling; successive trigger needling; relaxing needling; triple needling; quintuple needling; straight needling; Shu needling; short needling; superficial needling; yin needling; accompanied needling; and repeated shallow needling.
A technique to puncture the tenderness spots felt on the front (corresponding to the front-Mu point) and back (corresponding to the back-Shu point).
A technique to puncture migratory Ashi points: while needling directly at the tender point, searching for other tender points over the surrounding area and needling in succession.

A technique to insert the needle from the side of the tendon and then puncture the contracted
muscle in different directions to induce relaxation.
A technique to insert one needle perpendicularly, coupled with two more needles by its sides. Used to remove cold in a small, deeper area.

A technique to insert one needle perpendicularly in the centre, coupled with four more needles anterior, posterior, right, and left to the perpendicular needle. Used to remove cold in a large, shallow area.
A technique to pinch the skin and insert the needle subcutaneously (The wordâ€œstraightâ€here means towards the affected shallow area). Used to remove cold in the superficial area.

English term: Shu needling (one of the twelve needling techniques)
English definition/description: A technique to insert a needle perpendicularly to the deep area to wait for needling sensation and then slowly withdraw the needle when the needling sensation is present. Used to clear pathogenic heat.
A technique to insert the needle slowly while gently shaking the needle, followed by mild rotation when the needle is close to the bone. Used to treat bone pain or tenderness.
A technique to puncture the superficial area obliquely. Used indicated for muscle pain with a cold sensation.
A technique to puncture bilateral Taixi (KI 3) (the Yuan-primordial point of the kidney meridian) simultaneously. Used to treat cold limbs.

A technique to insert one needle perpendicularly, coupled with another one lateral to its side.
Indicated for tenderness or pain with a fixed location.
A technique to repeatedly puncture the shallow areas to cause bloodletting. Often used for carbuncles or abscesses.
null
A therapeutic method to apply burning mugwort (moxa) or other substances near or to particular points or areas of the body to relax, warm and tonify.
Processed moxa leaves that concentrates the white hairs on the underside of the leaf.
Cone-shaped mass made of moxa wool
A dosage unit to count the number of moxa cones.
A cigar-shaped roll of mugwort wrapped in cotton paper.
Moxa sticks containing medicinal powder.
A method to place a moxa cone directly or indirectly to the selected area and then ignite.
A method to place a moxa cone directly on the selected area and then ignite to create a superficial burn.
A method to place a small moxa cone directly on the skin, then ignite until the skin blisters and then scars after it heals.
Please refer to scarring moxibustion.
A method to place a small moxa cone directly on the skin, then ignite and remove the burning moxa before the skin burns enough to scar.
A direct moxibustion method using a wheat grain size moxa cone.
A method to place some insulated materials between the moxa cone and the skin.
A method to place a fresh ginger slice between the moxa cone and the skin.
A method to place a fresh garlic slice or mashed garlic between the moxa cone and the skin.
A method to place some salt (usually at Shenque (Ren 8)) between the moxa cone and the skin.
A method to place a monkshood cake between the moxa cone and the skin.
A method of indirect moxibustion where an ignited moxa stick or roll passes over a selected area without directly touching the surface to warm the area.
An indirect moxibustion method to hold a moxa stick above the skin during the treatment.
An indirect moxibustion method to keep the end of an ignited moxa stick at a fixed distance (2â€“3 cm) from the selected area, enabling a mild warm sensation.
An indirect moxibustion method to place an ignited moxa stick near the selected area and move it up and down like a pecking bird.
An indirect moxibustion method to keep the end of an ignited moxa stick at a fixed distance from the selected area and move it back and forth circularly.
An indirect moxibustion method to place several layers of cloth or cotton paper on the selected area and then press the ignited end of a moxa stick to allow the heat to penetrate the skin.

An indirect moxibustion method to apply an ignited moxa stick to the selected area. The moxa stick is made of fine powder of Tan Xiang (Lignum Santali Albi), Shan Nai (Rhizoma Kaempferiae), Qiang Huo (Rhizoma et Radix Notopterygii),
Gui Zhi (Ramulus Cinnamomi), Mu Xiang (Radix Aucklandiae), Xiong Huang (Realgar), Bai Zhi (Radix Angelicae Dahuricae) and Xi Xin (Radix et Rhizoma Asari).

An indirect moxibustion method to apply an ignited moxa stick to the selected area. The moxa stick is made of fine powder of Chen Xiang (Lignum Aquilariae Resinatum), Mu Xiang (Radix Aucklandiae), Ru Xiang (Olibanum), Yin Chen (Herba Artemisiae Scopariae), Qiang Huo (Rhizoma et Radix Notopterygii), Gan Jiang (Rhizoma Zingiberis), Chuan Shan Jia (Squama Manitis), and She Xiang(Moschus).
A method to fix a small section of moxa stick or cone onto the handle of an inserted needle prior to igniting.
A method to put moxa wool or stick into a metal box or canister, ignite and then place the box or canister over the selected area.
A method to apply a quick momentary touch to the selected area with an ignited oiled rush of Juncus.
A method to apply irritants to the selected area to produce congestion and blistering.
A method to apply warm or hot medicinal substances to acupuncture points.
null
A therapeutic method to create negative pressure by consuming the air inside the cup with fire or other methods and then place the cup on the skin over the selected area.

A method to create negative pressure by introducing an ignited material inside the cup  to consume the air, thereby enabling the cup to suck itself onto the skin. There are three different approaches: fire twinkling; fire throwing; and cotton sticking.

A method to ignite an alcoholic cotton ball held with a forceps, place it inside the cup, quickly turn it around in one to two circles, take it out immediately, and place the cup on the selected area.
A method whereby an ignited paper is quickly flung into a cup to create a negative pressure on the selected area.
A method to stick an alcoholic cotton ball on the inner wall (the lower 1/3), ignite the cotton ball and quickly place the cup over the selected area.

A method to boil a cup in water to create negative pressure: to hold the boiled bamboo cup (the mouth facing downwards) with a forceps, cover the cup mouth with a towel to absorb the water in the cup, and then quickly place the cup over the selected area.
Leave the cup in place after suction.
A method to lubricate the cup mouth and selected area first and then slide the cup up and down while retaining its suction.
A method to rapidly place and remove the cup repeatedly over the selected area until the local skin becomes red.
A method to prick the area to be treated with a three-edged needle or lancet and then suck out blood with a cup.
A method to apply cupping to the centre of the site where a needle is retained.
A boiling cup method to boil bamboo cups in medicinal liquid and then apply to the body.

A method to scrape the skin repeatedly using a soup spoon or other smooth-edged instruments (such as horned animal bones, water buffalo horn or jade). The skin is often lubricated with massage oil or water.
Guasha tools are often made from buffalo horn, Bian-stone or jade.
null

A Chinese medical therapy to apply manipulation to points or body areas for disease treatment and prevention as well as promoting health.
Sometimes, patients are educated to exercise in addition to receiving treatment.

Specific, standardized methods and movements to treat/prevent diseases and benefit health.
Tuina manipulations are supposed to be lasting, forceful, even, soft and penetrating to the deeper tissue.

A tuina manipulation to stick to the area to be treated with the fifth metacarpophalangeal joint and conduct back-and-forth rolling using the hypothenar eminence and the ulnar side of the back of the hand.

English term: Rolling manipulation with the proximal interphalangeal joints
English definition/description: A tuina manipulation to clench a fist to allow the distal phalanx bone of the thumb to be inside  the fist, stick to the area to be treated with the proximal interphalangeal joints of the index, middle, ring and little fingers and then apply back- and-forth rolling manipulation.
A tuina manipulation to exert constant force on the area to be treated with the tip or the palmar side of the thumb through active swing of the forearm.

English term: Yi Zhi Chan pushing with the radial side of the thumb
Pinyin term: yÃ¬ zhÇ chÃ¡n piÄn fÄ“ng tuÄ« fÇ
English definition/description: A variation of Yi Zhi Chan pushing manipulation using the radial side of the thumb.

English term: Fast Yi Zhi Chan pushing manipulation
English definition/description: A fast Yi Zhi Chan pushing manipulation with a frequency of more than 220 times/min.

English term: Yi Zhi Chan pushing with the flexed thumb
English definition/description: A variation of Yi Zhi Chan pushing manipulation with the radial or dorsal side of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.
A tuina manipulation to knead and exert force  on the area to be treated with the great thenar eminence through rhythmic swing of the forearm.

A tuina manipulation to apply perpendicular pressure to the surface of the body with the fingers, palms or elbows. The pressure is supposed to reach subcutaneous tissues. It includes kneading with the finger, kneading with the palm and kneading with the forearm.
A Tuina manipulation to rub the area to be treated circularly with the fingers or palms.
A one-way linear pushing manipulation with the fingers, palms, or elbows.
A pushing manipulation with the Hukou area (formed between the thumb and index finger).

A tuina manipulation to scrape with the radial side of the index finger, on the back of the interphalangeal joint of the index finger. Alternatively, scraping can be done with tools such as spoons or coins.
A tuina manipulation to apply linear rubbing with the hypothenar, great thenar, palms or fingers.
A tuina manipulation to apply top-down, left-right or arch-shaped wiping with the palmar side of the thumbs or the palms.

A tuina manipulation to apply perpendicular pressure to the surface of the body with the palmar side of the fingers, palms or elbows. It is also one of the common diagnostic methods in tuina practice.
A tuina manipulation to apply perpendicular pressure to the surface of the body with finger tips, interphalangeal joints or elbows.
A tuina manipulation to apply continuous, forceful pressure to the surface of the body with the palmar side of the thumbs, palms or elbows.
A tuina manipulation to apply symmetrical pressure to the area to be treated with the fingers or palms.
A tuina manipulation to apply rotating pressure to the area to be treated with the palms.
A tuina manipulation to apply pressure to the area to be treated with a fist.
A tuina manipulation to rub the palms and gently place (the warm palms) over the area to be treated.
A tuina manipulation to press the area to be treated with the palmar side of the thumbs.
A tuina manipulation to apply coordinated pressure to the area to be treated with the thumb and the other four fingers.

A tuina manipulation to place the palm over the area to be treated, grasp and lift the muscle either using the thumb and the other four fingers or exerting a symmetric force from the base of the palm and fingers, hold for a while and then shift forward to repeat the procedure.
A tuina manipulation to clamp and release the area to be treated with flexed index finger and middle finger or with the thumb and flexed index finger.

A tuina manipulation to place the index finger and middle finger together and flex into a hook, stick to the skin with the radial border of the middle phalanx of index finger and then apply continuous pushing and wiping manipulation.
A tuina manipulation to pinch and knead the area to be treated with the thumb and the other four fingers.
A tuina manipulation to grab and pinch the area to be treated with five fingertips.
A tuina manipulation to clutch and release the limb with the palm.
A tuina manipulation to hold the limb with both hands/palms and apply alternating or back-and- forth twisting.
A tuina manipulation to apply rhythmic grasping and pinching of the limb.
A tuina manipulation to hold the area to be treated with the thumb and index finger and apply back-and-forth twisting.
A tuina manipulation to press the area to be treated with fingers or elbows and then apply perpendicular plucking force to the subcutaneous tissue.
A tuina manipulation to pat the area to be treated with the palms or fingers.
A tuina manipulation to knock the surface of the body with the fist, palms, fingers or mulberry sticks.
A tuina manipulation to place the five fingers together and peck the area to be treated.
A tuina manipulation to tap the area to be treated with the ulnar side of the little finger or a hollow fist.
A tuina manipulation to chop the area between the fingers with the ulnar side of the palm.
A tuina manipulation to place one palm over the area to be treated and percuss the dorsum of the hand with a hollow fist made by the other hand.
A tuina manipulation to flip the area to be treated with fingernails or palmar sides of the fingers.
A tuina manipulation to grasp the affected limb and apply small-amplitude radial shakings.
A tuina manipulation to press acupuncture points or certain body parts with the fingers or palms and apply fast, continuous vibration.
A tuina manipulation to conduct passive rotation of the affected joint along the axis of motion.
A tuina manipulation to immobilize one end of the affected joint or limb and pull the other end along the longitudinal axis.
A tuina manipulation to clamp the affected fingers or toes with the fingers and apply rapid pulling.
A tuina manipulation to slowly and repeatedly flex and extend the joints to stretch the surrounding tissues, and increase the joint range of motion.
A tuina manipulation to apply a sudden thrust force to the affected joint to produce passive rotation, flexion, extension, abduction and adduction.
A tuina manipulation to carry the patient on the back and apply traction, shaking, vibration and instant extension to the affected lumbar vertebrae.
A tuina manipulation to place the palmar sides of the fingers over the area to be treated and apply soft, one-way combing.
A tuina manipulation to brush or scrub the surface of the body with the fingers.
A tuina manipulation to place the palm or fingers over the area to be treated, gradually push from the proximal end to the distal end, and then release the force quickly.
A tuina manipulation to gently cover the area to be treated with the hand and remain still.
A tuina manipulation to make a passive rotation of the joints.
A tuina manipulation to hold or lift the affected limb with one or both hands.
A tuina manipulation to press the limbs or acupuncture points with fingers to help with diagnosis.
A tuina manipulation to lift the post-traumatic sunken bones or joints to normal position using one or both hands or with the help of a rope.
A tuina manipulation to clamp and release the skin of the area to be treated with the ulnar aspects of both palms.
A tuina manipulation to squeeze both sides of the area to be treated with one or both hands.
A tuina manipulation to pull or move the limbs of the patient.

Pinyin term: tuÄ« nÃ¡ fÃ¹ hÃ© shÇ’u fÇ lÃ¨i
English definition/description: null
A compound tuina manipulation composed of pressing and kneading manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of grasping and kneading manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of Yi Zhi Chan pushing using the radial side of the thumb and rubbing circularly with the other four fingers.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of pulling-stretching and shaking manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of kneading and pinching manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of tendon-flicking and muscle plucking manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of pinching and lifting manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of Yi Zhi Chan pushing and kneading manipulation.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of plucking and pulling manipulations.
A compound tuina manipulation composed of hooking and point-pressing manipulations.
A tuina manipulation to push and scrub along the Shaoyang meridian in the temporal region using the radial side of the thumb and tips of the other four fingers.
A tuina manipulation to step with the feet on certain areas of the body.

A tuina manipulation to pinch and lift the skin of the spine symmetrically with the thumb, index finger and middle finger or with the thumb and the other four fingers and release the force immediately. Move forward gradually and repeat the same procedure.
A tuina manipulation to press the bladder meridian on both sides of the spine.
A tuina manipulation to insert the fingers into the space between the scapula and thoracic wall. It is specifically used for gastroptosis.
A tuina manipulation to lift the affected area with one or both hands. It is commonly used for gastroptosis.

A tuina manipulation: Place the palms on the lower borders of the subcostal region and extend gradually to the low back, press and knead the soft tissues on both sides of the low back using the palmar sides of the fingers, lift the low back and abdomen and then swing to the left and right gently.
A tuina manipulation to place the thumbs and the middle fingers over the lumbar triangles on both sides and apply soft, gentle pressure.
A tuina manipulation to press the low back coupled with traction and stretching.

Pinyin term: jÇ zhÃ¹ tuÄ« nÃ¡ shÇ’u fÇ lÃ¨i
English definition/description: Manipulations used on the spine to correct spinal subluxation and regulate the functions of the spine.
Lotions applied to the surface of the body for lubrication or treatment.

Pinyin term: tuÄ« nÃ¡ fÇ” zhÃ¹ qÃ¬ jÃ¹ lÃ¨i
English definition/description: Supplementary tools to assist in tuina treatment and health care.

An assistant tuina tool made of 12 specific mulberry branches based on certain requirements with a strong effect to unblock and circulate qi and blood. It is often used on the top of the head, chest and back, waist, hip and limbs.

An assistant tuina tool comprising an iron bar with five to six pieces of jade or sandalwood made into a chain of beads. The head and tail of the iron bar are folded. The appliance is connected to a short handle and can be held in the hand and the beads work like a rolling wheel. It is often used on the face, bone joints, etc.

A type of tuina therapy based on the theory of traditional Chinese medicine, using specific manipulations on the meridians and collaterals and specific points on the surface of the body.   It helps to prevent against diseases and benefit health through harmonizing Zangâ€“Fu organs, yin, yang, qi and blood, strengthen the body and promote the healthy growth and development of children.

A main training method in tuina exercise and a key part of Neigong tuina. It is originally a form of martial art to strengthen the body, but now becomes a distinctive method and school of self- exercise plus tuina treatment.
A traditional health-building exercise to stretch the body, strengthen the sinews, bones and ligaments and regulate the meridians and zangâ€“fu organs.

Pinyin term: qÃ­ tÄ tuÄ« nÃ¡ shÃ¹ yÇ”
English definition/description: null
A common external therapy in Chinese medicine to treat diseases through heat stimulation.
A therapeutic method to apply herbal ointment on the surface of the area to be treated, followed by tuina manipulations.
One of the pain control methods in Chinese medicine by applying Tuina to reduce or control pain according to theories of Chinese medicine.
A tuina method for healthy people or people with suboptimal health to strengthen the body and help with disease prevention and treatment.
A type of tuina method to achieve healthier skin and slow down the ageing process of the skin.
null

To guide qi to harmonize the body and stretch the body to make it soft. It aims to prevent and cure diseases and promote health through stretching exercise combined with breath and internal qi circulation.

An exercise method to regulate the body, breath and mind to achieve body-mind, man-society and man-nature harmonization. It cultivates the essence, qi and spirit internally and sinews, bones and body externally according to ancient Chinese philosophy.

Originated in Daoism, it refers to the second stage of internal alchemical process (i.e., to refine qi to spirit). This is performed on the basis of the small heavenly circle exercise and is believed that the large heavenly circle can connect spirit with qi, improve health and attain longevity.

The three areas in the ascending path along the Du meridian when internal qi circulates along  the pathways of the Du and Ren meridians  during practicing theâ€œsmall heavenly circleâ€(or â€œmicrocosmic orbitâ€) meditation. They are arduous for internal qi to overcome and therefore calledâ€œpassesâ€orâ€œbarriersâ€. Alternatively,
they refer to the three steps in internal alchemy (Neidan): refining the essence to qi; refining the qi to spirit; and refining the spirit to emptiness. Some also use three passes to represent the ears, eyes and mouth.

English term: Harmony of the eyes, ears, nose and tongue
English definition/description: A specific state in qigong practice that requires dropping the eyelids, listening to the silence, regulating breathing by focusing the eyes on the tip of the nose and closing the mouth. This state helps to remove distracting thoughts during qigong practice.

A state of peaceful inner joy and free from ego or desires. This principle on health cultivation was recorded in the Huang Di Nei Jing (Yellow Emperorâ€™s Internal Classic) and highly valued by generations of qigong masters.
A beneficial variation of natural breathing with the Dantian area. Unlike usual abdominal breathing, this breathing method does not need mental focus or external force.

Taiji is an ancient Chinese philosophical term which represents the state of undifferentiated absolute and infinite potential; the oneness before duality, from which yin and yang, the basic polarity of the universe, originate. It has later become the highest conceivable principle about the generation, development and changes of all things in the universe. Taiji is often considered as the root and symbol of traditional Chinese culture. It has far-reaching impact on the Yi Jing (the Book of Changes), traditional Chinese medicine and taijiquan.

An ancient Chinese martial art practiced for both defence training and health benefits. It   is a combination of breathing, mental focus, and physical movements, whose intention is to
cultivate the practitionerâ€™s internal qi. It is rooted in the philosophies of Confucianism, Daoism and Chinese medicine, and concepts of Taiji, yin-yang and the Five Elements.

Pinyin term: tÃ i jÃ­ quÃ¡n liÃº pÃ i
English definition/description: Major influential taijiquan styles include Chen style, yang style, WÃº style, WÇ” style, Sun style and Zhaobao style.

Pinyin term: tÃ i jÃ­ quÃ¡n quÃ¡n lÇ
English definition/description: The principles of taijiquan are based on its philosophical and medical meaning as well as practice requirements. They include Taiji theories, mnemonics and classics.
The tips or smart ways in Taiji practice. These include mnemonics for taijiquan, Taiji sword, Taiji spear, Taiji knife and Taiji pushing hands. These mnemonics are often vivid and conversational.

A catalogue to record categories or systems. There are three types of Taiji manuals: 1) the names
of sequenced Taiji skills and weapons routines/ forms; 2) Inheritance lineage; and 3) books on Taiji skills.
Classics/texts which are exclusively focussed on the essential principles that guide the practice of taijiquan.
Intangible frame and rhythm, including physical moves, eye movement and connections or transitions between moves.

It refers to Wudang martial arts (occupied with spiritual, mental or qi-related aspects), as opposed to Shaolin (external) martial arts (focused on physical aspects). There are three
internal martial arts: taijiquan, xingyiquan (form- intention fist) and baguazhang (eight trigram palm).
A series of movements in Taiji practice.

These include four sides and four corners. If we consider taijiquan as a 3-D ball, symmetrical release of forces from eight directions (left, right, up, down and two diagonal angles) is essential  to maintain the body equilibrium, known as the â€œrounded forceâ€.
Vertex, crotch, heart, eyes, ears, hands, feet and waist.

English term: Eight types of people should be declined to learn Taiji
English definition/description: Those with no loyalty or filial piety; those with no humanistic spirit; those with evil intentions; those who are reckless and impulsive; those who are defiant and arrogant; those who are rude and disrespectful; those who are unpredictable; and those who care too much about gains and losses.
Avoid using strength to store qi; avoid expanding the chest or sinking the low back; avoid shrugging the shoulders or sinking the neck; avoid discontinuity in body moves.

Relax the shoulders and sink the elbows; lift the vertex and issue force from the thighs; tap the teeth and touch the palate with the tongue; sink the chest and loosen the waist; move naturally; internal-external unity; yin-yang coordination; and stillness in movement.

An ancient philosophical term, referring to the primordial universe prior to the Taiji (supreme ultimate). In Taiji practice, it has three extended meanings: 1) a relatively static state; 2) mental serenity before body moves in Taiji practice;
3) abdomen.

An ancient philosophical term, referring to yin and yang. In Taiji practice, the two forms have three extended meanings: 1) movement and stillness;
2) symmetrical Taiji moves; 3) the two kidneys.
An ancient philosophical term, referring to heaven, earth and man. In Taiji practice, it is used to represent head, hands and feet, further indicating the upper, middle and lower body parts.
An ancient philosophical term. It has two meanings in Taiji: 1) upper and lower limbs; 2) four directionsâ€”front, back, left and right.

These include health benefits and self-defence training. Health benefits are achieved through practicing taolu (solo hand and weapons routines/ forms). Self-defence training mainly refers to pushing hands sequences, which embody a variety of self-defence techniques.

The six closings include three internal harmonies (intent, qi and strength) and three external ones (shoulder-hip, elbow-knee and hands-feet). These harmonies allow the movements to connect seamlessly and the force to be intact.
A symbol or diagram in Chinese philosophy representing Taiji and its dualist aspectsâ€”yin and yang.

English term: Hold the head as if suspended from above
English definition/description: The head is held as if suspended by a thread attached to the crown, at the point Baihui (Du20). This posture aims to avoid tension in the neck. In doing so, do not tilt the head from side to side, or up and down. The whole body is light and nimble when the head is suspended at the crown.

English term: Relax the shoulders, sink the elbows
English definition/description: Relax and drop down the shoulders, especially the acromion, or the point Jianjing (GB 21); at the same time, slightly flex and drop the elbow.
A technique to protect the stomach in Taiji practice. It produces a similar effect as dropping the elbow.

Extend and relax the fingers naturally, slightly separating them to form an arc or spiral at the back of the hand. This enables the internal  qi to radiate to the fingers and is known as
â€œmaterializing in the hands and fingersâ€.
During Taiji practice, the movement of one arm triggers corresponding movement in the other one, as if they are connected to each other by a cord.
Keep the wrist and fingers in a vertical position (approximately 90Âº). However, it is advisable not to use force to bend the wrist.
Drop and relax the wrist to allow the internal energy to reach the fingertips from the arm.
Pump the wrist to soften and relax the hands.
Make the wrist straight and flat.
Place one wrist over the other.

English term: Sink the chest, raise the back
English definition/description: Intentionally relax the chest and back muscles and intercostal space. The shoulders should be naturally rounded to allow the chest to be slightly hollowed. Toâ€œraise the backâ€means to stretch the spine longitudinally and horizontally to allow the qi to stick to the back (so that one can use this qi to issue great power).
Expanding the back is closely associated with sinking the chest. By sinking the chest, one will be able to expand the back naturally.

English term: Keep the waist relaxed and buttocks tucked under
English definition/description: To relax the waist means to lift the coccyx and sink the points Shensu (BL 23) and Mingmen (DU 4). To tuck buttocks under means to slightly tuck in the buttocks.

English term: Keep the waist sunken and buttocks tucked under
English definition/description: By sinking the waist in a relaxed sitting position, one will be able to tuck in the buttocks naturally.
During Taiji practice, the coccyx needs to be kept upright at all times.
To lift the anus, tuck in the coccyx and keep the body neutral. This helps to maintain balance and feel comfortable.

English term: Keep the upper and lower connected
Pinyin term: shÃ ng xiÃ  yÃ­ xiÃ n
English definition/description: To make Baihui (DU 20) and Huiyin (REN 1) vertically connected, in order to keep the upper body aligned and upright; and to connect Jianjing (GB 21) with Yongquan (KI 1) to keep the head and feet vertically connected.

To keep the torso perpendicular to the ground and place the bodyweight over the supporting feet.
This helps to keep the body stable.

To lengthen the torso throughâ€œholding the head as if suspended from aboveâ€. To extend the arms through sinking the shoulders and dropping the elbows. To lengthen the legs through relaxing the waist, opening the hips and flexing the knees.

The five bows include the torso, both hands and both feet. The body bow uses the waist as the handle and uses Yamen (DU 15) and coccyx as the tips. The hand bow uses the elbow as the handle and uses the wrist and clavicle as the tips. The foot bow uses the knee as the handle and uses the hip and heel as the tips.
To attempt to float the buttocks before issuing internal energy.
To relax and drop the buttocks when squatting down.
To slightly tuck in the buttocks to facilitate the abdomen and relax the crotch. This helps to keep the body neutral and stable.
To relax the hip joint, relax hip muscles and tuck in the femoral head. This enables the crotch to become round.

English term: Relax and tuck in the hips
English definition/description: To relax and, at the same time, tuck in the hips to enable the perineum to become a semicircle.

To adduct the knees intentionally to protect the crotch. This helps to distinguish empty from solid, keep the lower body stable and increase the loading ability of the legs. This can also lengthen the legs.
A common error in Taiji practice. Slack crotch may cause energy to scatter.
A common error in Taiji practice. A sharp-angled crotch may cause an inability to support the internal energy.
A common error in Taiji practice. An open crotch (>90Âº) may cause an inability to obtain the internal energy.
To appropriately flex the knee to enable the body weight to be placed on the flexed leg.

Movement combination of the body, breathing and energy. Theâ€œopeningâ€refers to eccentric movements of the arms, whereas theâ€œclosingâ€ refers to concentric movements of the arms.
Breathing in and releasing energy act to open, whereas breathing out and storing energy act to close.
Toâ€œstore energyâ€means to relax muscles with mental focus. Toâ€œrelease energyâ€means to contract muscles and often combine with breathing.
A dynamic state in Taiji practice. Taiji movements are open, continuous and transitional like a river; however, they can also close and become static like mountains.
Taiji movements are relatively slower than other martial arts; the speed of movement varies among differing styles.

In Taiji practice, it is important to distinguish between fullness and emptiness all over the body (i.e. we must know exactly which part of our body is issuing power and which part is receiving it). As for the legs, theâ€œemptyâ€leg is never absolutely weightless, and theâ€œfullâ€leg does not have all the weight placed upon it.

The principles of Taiji exercise. Theâ€œopeningâ€ means to stretch, step forward, bend down and drop. Theâ€œclosingâ€means to flex, step backward, raise and lift. Theâ€œemptyâ€means absence of mental focus, supplementary force, relaxation and closing movements. Theâ€œsolidâ€means presence of mental focus, major force point and opening movements.
The coordination or harmony between mental intent and physical movement. Theâ€œunityâ€here means a perfect and natural combination between hands, feet and mental intent.

Coordinated movements of the upper and lower limbs as well as the torso. Hand movements, waist movements, leg movements, and even the eye movements â€” all are in one unified movement (The root is in the feet, released through the legs, controlled by the waist, and materialized in the hands and fingers).

Pinyin term: jiÃ© jiÃ© guÃ n chuÃ n
English definition/description: This refers to successive movement of nine major joints throughout the body: neck, back, low back, hip, knee, ankle, shoulder, elbow and wrist.

A distinctive feature of taijiquan. Mindfulness orâ€œintentâ€guides the body movement and breathing; both breathing and internal qi are controlled by the mindfulness of the will. The â€œgentleâ€means to guide movements with intent instead of force. Theâ€œflexibleâ€means to move the arms or legs with agility.

Pinyin term: yÃ­ dÃ²ng wÃº yÇ’u bÃº dÃ²ng
English definition/description: The power is rooted in the feet, controlled by the waist, and manifested through the fingers, integrating the body as one harmonious unit.
Force and changes of taijiquan. Theâ€œhardâ€refers to fast, short release of force in an attack, whereas theâ€œsoftâ€refers to slow, gentle and spiral moves in defence.
The two technical features of Taiji. Theâ€œsquareâ€ refers to the force points, whereas theâ€œroundâ€ refers to arc-shaped Taiji movements. The two features are unity of opposites.

English term: Mutual generation of square and round
English definition/description: Theâ€œsquareâ€refers to the hard power point that manifests in four sides and four corners. The â€œroundâ€refers to the soft, circulating qi. The â€œsquareâ€originates from theâ€œroundâ€, and the â€œroundâ€contains theâ€œsquareâ€. There isâ€œsquareâ€ within theâ€œroundâ€and vice versa.

These include eight force-releasing methods and five footwork methods. The eight force-releasing methods include four straight directions (Peng, LÇš, Ji and An) and four diagonal directions (Cai, Lie, Zhou and Kao). The five footwork methods are called step forward, step backward, gaze (that is, focus your intention toward and move) to the left, gaze to the right, and central equilibrium.
A collective term for a variety of power or energy developed through Taiji practice.

Theâ€œZhongâ€means the centre in direction. The â€œTuâ€means earth in five elements. Together they mean theâ€œcentreâ€or body weight. In Taiji practice, it is important to distinguish empty and full in all body parts as well as the two legs.

English term: Defeat the strong with minimal effort
English definition/description: â€˜A force of four ounces deflects a thousand poundsâ€™(i.e. to repel force effortlessly).

Theâ€œJinâ€originally means strong and powerful. In Taiji practice, it refers to the cultivated, trained and flexible force that can change in power, direction, force point and force speed, in response to an opponentâ€™s attack.
To sink qi to Dantian, you need to keep the coccyx upright, sink the chest, relax the shoulders and suspend the crotch, and thus to guide qi down to the abdomen with intent.

English term: Opening with breathing out and closing with breathing in
English definition/description: An essential principle in coordinated movements and breathing: breathe out when performing opening, solid, stretching, stepping forward, dropping, bending down, moving away, releasing, attacking or striking moves; and breathe in when performing closing, empty, sinking, flexing, stepping backward, lifting, moving back, raising, collecting, and softening moves.

English term: Opening with breathing in and closing with breathing out
English definition/description: An essential principle in coordinated movements and breathing: breathe in when opening up the rib cage and breathe out when closing the rib cage.
A distinctive feature of taijiquan. Theâ€œintentâ€ means to guide the body movement and breathing with mental intent. Theâ€œqiâ€means both breathing and internal qi are controlled by mental intent.
A distinctive feature of taijiquan. Theâ€œShenâ€ includes spirit and eye direction. Theâ€œqiâ€ means breathing and internal qi move with body movement.

An important feature of Taiji practice. There is       a saying that it takes at least 10 years to really understand Taiji. The key part is learning to cultivate internal energy through relaxation and stillness. It is necessary to avoid tension and mental stress before achieving relaxation in Taiji practice.

English term: Issue forces from the four extremities
English definition/description: Intentionally projecting internal force through the tips of fingers and toes.
Basic skills acquired through learning standard Taiji moves and pushing hands. These  require continuous practice and include both psychological and physiological abilities.
A weaponry (sword) form of Taiji practice, based on ancient fencing technique, coupled with fencing arts from other schools of martial arts.
A combination of taijiquan and skills of playing with a fan. It moves or rotates the fan with intent and acts to benefit health, uplift the mood, and entertain yourself and others.
A weaponry (spear) form of Taiji practice. The spear is long, sharp and easy to use. It is known as theâ€œking of weaponsâ€because of the significant military advantage it provides on battlefields.

A Taiji practice, which uses a cane or stick as a weapon. The stick is known as theâ€œhead of weaponsâ€. There were no standard Taiji cane forms before 1949, with the exception of the White Ape form in Chen style Taiji. After 1949,
martial arts masters including Cui Yishi developed Taiji cane forms.

Also known as hitting hands, kneading hands or crossing hands, pushing hands is a two-person training routine practiced in Taiji. It works to undo a personâ€™s natural instinct to resist force with force, teaching the body to yield to force and redirect it. There are mainly eight methods in practicing pushing hands: bing-warding off; lÇš-rolling back; ji-pressing; an-pushing; cai- plucking; lie-splitting; zhou- elbow striking; and kao-shoulder striking.

Rising or expanding internal energy. With this energy, one feels the body is full of qi in all eight directions. During pushing hands, this energy allows you to create a buffer zone that prevents the first shock of an incoming attack and at the same time, enable you to defend, absorb or redirect the opponentâ€™s power.
The use of force in a sideways direction, such as where we intercept and move with a forward directed attack, simultaneously diverting it slightly to one side and thus to empty space.

Internal energy that projects forward from its source to prevent your opponent from issuing strength. During pushing hands, this energy radiates along the outside of the forearms and the back of the hands.

A forward and downward movement of energy. During pushing hands, this energy enables you to prevent your opponent from raising their arms or legs, and at the same time, allows you to stick to and redirect the opponentâ€™s power.
Internal energy that grasps or pulls the opponentâ€™s wrist or elbow downwards with the fingertips or palm.
Internal energy to push or pluck forward. During pushing hands, this energy allows you to use a spiral motion to split the opponentâ€™s body and destroy the opponentâ€™s balance.

Internal energy that projects through the forearm rotation and tip of the elbow. During pushing hands, you can either defend the opponentâ€™s attack with the tip of your elbow. Alternatively, you can use one hand to stick to the opponentâ€™s hand and use flexed elbow of the other arm to spirally press the opponentâ€™s elbow and arm.
Internal energy to squeeze forward with your shoulder, back and hip. During pushing hands, this energy allows you to push the opponent with your shoulder, back or hip.
A wrong move in pushing hands.
Rigid, inflexible moves during pushing hands.
Connection and transition between empty and solid moves.
This is opposed to a stance with equal weight on both feet. Single weighted stance refers to the body weight focusing on one foot.
One of the eight methods in pushing hands: An upward circular movement, forward or backward, yielding or offsetting usually with the arms to disrupt the opponentâ€™s centre of gravity.
One of the eight methods in pushing hands: to apply sideways, circular yielding movement to the opponentâ€™s wrist with one hand and stick to the opponentâ€™s elbow with the other hand.
One of the eight methods in pushing hands: A pressing or squeezing offset in a direction away from the body, usually done with the back of the hand or outside edge of the forearm.
One of the eight methods in pushing hands: to grasp the opponentâ€™s wrist or elbow downwards with the fingertips or palm.

One of the eight methods in pushing hands: to separate, to twist or to offset with a spiral motion, often while making immobile part of the body (such as a hand or leg) to split an opponentâ€™s body thereby destroying posture and balance.
One of the eight methods in pushing hands: to strike or push with the elbow.
One of the eight methods in pushing hands: to strike or push with the shoulder, upper back, arm or hip.

Two basic skills in the practice of Taiji pushing hands. Toâ€œadhereâ€means to get your opponent to follow you under your control; whereas to â€œfollowâ€means to obey your opponentâ€™s intention by letting him think he can apply an application, which leads him to use force.
A weaponry (broadsword) form of Taiji practice, which includes the philosophy, training and thirteen standard forms.
Methods to treat disordered moods and emotions using Chinese medicine theories on emotions.

A psychotherapeutic treatment protocol that combines analysis of causative factors of mental- emotional disorders with prayer. These analyses and prayer treatments are based on emotion theories and psychological principles in Chinese medicine.

A psychotherapeutic method that uses the mutual restraint cycle of five element theory in the treatment of mental-emotional disorders, during which the doctor intentionally arouses certain feelings in the patient that counteract their abnormal emotional state.

An emotion therapy based on the restraining cycle of the five-element theory: sadness corresponds to metal; anger corresponds to wood; metal restrains wood; so sad feelings and language will subdue or release anger.

An emotion therapy based on the restraining cycle of the five-element theory: anger corresponds to wood; thinking corresponds to earth; and wood restrains earth; so provocation to elicit an angry response will relieve anxiety and over-thinking.

An emotion therapy based on the restraining cycle of the five-element theory: thinking corresponds to earth; fear corresponds to water; earth restrains water; so encouraging mental focus or meditation can help the patient ignore or forget fear.

An emotion therapy based on the restraining cycle of the five-element theory: fear corresponds to water; joy corresponds to fire; water restrains fire; so eliciting a fearful response will restrain excess joy and euphoria.

An emotion therapy based on the restraining cycle of the five-element theory: joy corresponds to fire; sadness corresponds to metal; fire restrains metal; and so happiness can overcome melancholy and sorrow.

Flexible psychotherapeutic methods that apply the mutual promotion or mutual restraint relationship among the five phases to different mental-emotional disorders. This idea was first mentioned in the Su Wen and later promulgated by Zhu Danxi.

A method to treat mental-emotional diseases such as anxiety, panic and post-traumatic stress disorders. Under controlled conditions, by repeated exposure to the circumstance that
trigger the patientâ€™s anxiety or traumatic response disorder, their adverse reaction is gradually lessened and normalized.
A method to use different qualities of the five musical tones (gong, shang, jiao, zheng and yu), related to the five elements in the treatment of mental disorders.
A method to treat mental disorders by communicating with the patientâ€™s self-image.
Joy, anger, grief, excess thinking and fear.
Pathological conditions that result from excessive mental activity impairing the essential qi of five zang organs and/or disturbing qi movement within zangâ€“fu organs.

English term: Fright causes the qi to become chaotic
English definition/description: Sudden shock and fright disrupt the qi activity and causes qi movements to become confused and disorderly.

English term: Fear causes the qi to descend
English definition/description: Excess fear or an ongoing state of fearfulness causes qi to strongly descend.

English term: Joy causes the qi to slack
English definition/description: Excess joy and/or euphoria cause qi to move too slowly and the qi movement becomes sluggish.
Excess sorrow and grief weaken the qi.

English term: Anger causes the qi to rise
English definition/description: Rage and persistent anger cause disorderly ascending of the qi.
null
The study of essential knowledge and use of diet as part of therapy.
Food prepared in combination with Chinese herbs to benefit the health, where the selection of the herbs is based on the theories of Chinese medicine.

A therapeutic approach to harmonize qi and blood, balance yin and yang, prevent disease and benefit health, through the use of specifically tailored diets, where the properties of the food ingredients are guided by the theories of Chinese medicine.
